• The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) is responsible for processing millions of immigration benefit applications each year, determining eligibility, and detecting suspicious information to refer for fraud investigation. In fiscal year 2005, USCIS received about 6.3 million applications and adjudicated about 7.5 million applications.
• USCIS has taken steps to enhance its fraud control efforts, including establishing the Office of Fraud Detection and National Security (FDNS) to serve as its focal point for addressing immigration benefit fraud. However, USCIS lacks a comprehensive approach for managing risk, a monitoring mechanism to ensure that knowledge arising from routine operations informs the assessment of policies and procedures, and clear communication regarding how to balance multiple agency objectives.
• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Homeland Security direct the Director of USCIS to enhance its risk management approach, implement a mechanism to feed back information about fraud vulnerabilities, communicate clearly to USCIS adjudicators the importance of fraud prevention-related objectives, provide USCIS adjudicator staff with access to relevant internal and external information, and establish output and outcome-based performance goals to assess the effectiveness of fraud control efforts.
</summary>

<summary>
• The General Accounting Office (GAO) assessed the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) performance during the 1994 filing season, focusing on processing income tax returns and refunds accurately and efficiently, and providing taxpayers with access to forms, information, and electronic filing methods.
• The GAO validated the results of a service center's test of refund accuracy and timeliness by reviewing 853 randomly selected refunds, and analyzed filing season-related data from IRS' Management Information System and processing errors, including those involving the Earned Income Credit (EIC).
• The GAO found that IRS' computer systems generally performed well during the 1994 filing season, but some systems problems occurred, causing downtime for IRS employees and short delays in refunds for taxpayers.
• The GAO also found that the EIC continued to be a leading source of errors by taxpayers and tax practitioners in preparing returns, contributing to IRS' error resolution workload, and that the number of fraudulent refund claims identified by IRS continued to grow at a troubling pace.
• The GAO noted that taxpayers experienced considerable difficulty reaching IRS over the telephone, and that the accessibility of IRS' toll-free telephone assistance declined in 1994, while the accuracy of answers to tax law questions remained the same.
• The GAO concluded that while IRS achieved many of its goals for processing tax returns and assisting taxpayers, there continue to be some serious problems, including detected refund fraud, EIC-related errors, and difficulties reaching IRS by telephone, and recommended that IRS continue to address these issues.
</summary>

<summary>

• Medicaid was established in 1965 as a jointly funded federal-state program providing medical assistance to qualified low-income persons, with each state designing and administering its own program subject to federal requirements.

• In 1993, Tennessee submitted a waiver application to the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) under section 1115 of the Social Security Act, which allowed the state to move its Medicaid program to a capitated managed care system.

• The TennCare program, which began on January 1, 1994, aimed to expand coverage to the uninsured population and control total program and state costs, with a budget-neutral requirement for HCFA approval.

• The state-federal sharing arrangements of the financing plan favored the state, allowing it to effectively reduce its share of total spending, and the waiver included provisions to monitor and ensure enrollee access to quality care.

• TennCare expanded health coverage by allowing non-Medicaid eligible persons to enroll and by extending the period of coverage for Medicaid-eligible persons, and it increased the scope of coverage by lifting restrictions on many services.

• The state set capitation rates that were substantially below historical Medicaid costs, and it discontinued its Disproportionate Share Hospital (DSH) program and established a smaller Primary Care Provider Fund.

• The federal spending limits applied to the entire TennCare program, including services not part of the capitated managed care program, and the state had flexibility in annual spending as long as the cumulative annual spending limits were not exceeded by more than the set percentage.

• The TennCare program had several benefits to the state, including reducing its funding of other state programs that served the uninsured and uninsurable populations, and allowing the state to claim hospital losses incurred in caring for TennCare eligibles as TennCare expenses.

• The state's quality assurance program was slow to implement, and HCFA required the state to develop interim monitoring strategies to ensure access and quality, and the state's progress in implementing its quality assurance monitoring plan was slow.

• The TennCare program faced several challenges, including the financial performance of the managed care organizations (MCOs), which lost money in the first year, and the state's ability to maintain adequate provider networks, which was uncertain due to the lack of experience with capitated managed care and the magnitude of the changes.

</summary>

<summary>

* The rapid increase in crack cocaine use in the 1980s was referred to as a drug epidemic, and researchers and government agencies look for changing patterns in drug use to identify emerging problems. These patterns include the use of a new illicit drug, a change in how a drug is taken, a change in the level of use among populations, and the use of a drug by a new population group or in a different geographic area.
* The National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) sponsored several surveys and convened a work group of epidemiologists to help identify and monitor changes in drug use patterns, but limitations in the drug detection mechanisms used by NIDA hindered the identification and monitoring of drug use activity in many geographic areas and for some high-risk populations.
* The federal public health response to crack in the 1980s primarily focused on cocaine in general instead of on crack specifically, and NIDA's research activities did not make clear distinctions between powdered cocaine and its crystallized form, crack. However, NIDA modified its drug detection mechanisms, and new federal mechanisms were created to address some of the coverage, timeliness, and methodological concerns raised by the Congress and others.
* The Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) was created to develop and coordinate a national drug control strategy, and ONDCP's 1997 strategy provided a common set of goals and objectives for drug control agencies to use in addressing drug use problems. However, concerns remain about the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the federal drug data collection system, and a more defined strategy for responding to emerging drug use problems is needed.

</summary>

<summary>
• The worker-profiling initiative was implemented in the US in the 1990s to identify unemployment claimants who are most likely to exhaust benefits and provide them with reemployment services. The initiative requires states to use statistical models or characteristic screens to identify claimants, and to refer them to services such as job search assistance and training. However, our analysis found that many states have not updated their profiling models in recent years, and that the reemployment services offered in the states we studied did not conform to the robust service process originally outlined by Labor.
• Despite the potential benefits of the worker-profiling initiative, our analysis also found that the data collected by Labor on the outcomes of referred claimants are of limited reliability, and that the national data on the worker-profiling initiative is of very limited usefulness as a measure of program activity, outcomes, and effectiveness. We recommend that the Secretary of Labor reevaluate the agency's worker-profiling data collection, ensure that the Employment and Training Administration takes a more active role to help ensure the accuracy of state profiling models, and encourage states to adhere to Labor's vision for in-depth reemployment services.
</summary>

<summary>
• The military health system has three missions: maintaining the health of active-duty service members, maintaining readiness, and providing care to dependents and retirees. 
• In 1999, the Department of Defense (DOD) spent about $16 billion on health care, with over $1 billion going towards the care of seniors.
• The TRICARE framework was implemented in the mid-1990s to improve beneficiary access and quality while containing costs. It offers three options: TRICARE Prime, TRICARE Extra, and TRICARE Standard.
• Military retirees aged 65 or older are eligible for Medicare, which covers health care expenses of the elderly, people with disabilities, and those with end-stage kidney disease.
• The Medicare subvention demonstration allowed DOD to create managed care organizations that participate in the Medicare+Choice program and enroll older retirees. The demonstration was authorized for a 3-year period beginning on January 1, 1998, and ending on December 31, 2000.
• The demonstration resulted in higher costs for DOD due to the high utilization of services by Senior Prime enrollees, who were hospitalized 41 percent more often and had 58 percent more outpatient visits than similar Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries.
• The BBA payment rules prevented the government from paying twice for the same care and protected the Medicare program from a large increase in its spending for Senior Prime enrollees, but DOD incurred greater costs for seniors due to the demonstration and covered these costs by redirecting funds from other uses.
</summary>

<summary>

* The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has made significant progress in implementing leading management practices in eight areas, including communication, strategic planning, IT, knowledge management, organizational structure, human capital management, training, and financial management.
* NTSB has fully implemented three management recommendations as of 2008, and has made further progress on eight other recommendations since then.
* The agency has fully implemented an IT strategic plan, undergone annual independent audits, and hired outside contractors to perform security testing and evaluation of its computer systems.
* NTSB has also made significant progress in limiting local administrator privileges, drafting a strategic training plan, and developing a full cost accounting system.
* However, the agency has not yet fully implemented four management recommendations, including improving knowledge management, human capital planning, and increasing the use of safety studies.
* NTSB has undertaken several initiatives to create a stronger, more diverse pool of candidates for external positions, including the establishment of a Management Candidate Program and an Executive Development Program.
* The agency has also made progress in increasing the use of the Training Center, including subleasing all available office space and increasing revenues by over $1.1 million.
* NTSB has proposed substantive and technical changes to its existing authorizing legislation, including the statutory authority to investigate incidents in addition to accidents, and reducing requirements for investigating rail and maritime accidents.
* The proposed changes would give NTSB expanded investigatory discretion, but also require the agency to be transparent in providing information about investigation criteria.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Government Performance and Results Act (GPRA) aims to shift the focus of government decision-making from activities and processes to results and outcomes achieved by federal programs.
* GPRA requires federal agencies to submit annual performance plans and reports, which provide information on performance goals, measures, strategies, and resources.
* The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has implemented GPRA and submitted annual performance plans and reports, which provide information on its performance in achieving its selected key outcomes.
* EPA's performance report for fiscal year 2000 showed progress in achieving its long-term goal of safe and healthy air in communities, including improvements in air quality and reductions in airborne toxic emissions.
* However, EPA's performance report acknowledged data limitations and inaccuracies in its Aerometric Information Retrieval System, which may affect the accuracy of its performance data.
* EPA's strategy for achieving its goal of improving air quality involves working with states, tribes, and local governments to achieve compliance with National Ambient Air Quality Standards.
* EPA's performance report for fiscal year 2000 also showed progress in achieving its goal of safe and clean drinking water, including improvements in water quality and reductions in exposure to contaminated recreational waters.
* However, EPA's performance report acknowledged data limitations and inaccuracies in its Safe Drinking Water Information System, which may affect the accuracy of its performance data.
* EPA's performance plan for fiscal year 2002 reflects changes to its performance goals and objectives, including a focus on developing outcome-based program goals.
* EPA's performance plan also includes goals and measures related to human capital, information security, and environmental and performance information management, but lacks specific goals and measures related to improving working relationships with states.

</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) launched the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices, make better use of information technology, and eliminate duplicative information systems. The initiative's primary objective is to significantly improve business processes of all functional areas through techniques such as business process reengineering and continuous process improvements.
* The CIM initiative has faced challenges, including a shift in focus from business process improvements to the selection and implementation of migration systems. This shift has raised concerns that it may delay significant improvement of logistics processes, result in the deployment of information systems that do not meet services' and DLA's operational requirements, and divert funds from ongoing improvement projects.
* The Joint Logistics System Center (JLSC) has been established to oversee the implementation of CIM in the logistics functions of materiel management and depot maintenance. JLSC has selected 32 migration systems for materiel management and depot maintenance, but its ability to successfully implement its strategy is jeopardized by impediments such as a lack of acceptance by DOD functional and technical managers, unclear program management authority, and the need for integration of CIM efforts across DOD business areas.
* To overcome these impediments, the Secretary of Defense is recommended to revise the CIM management strategy to ensure active participation and leadership by functional managers, train DOD employees to promote understanding and acceptance of changes, and change the name of the CIM initiative to more accurately communicate its primary objective.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) conducted an undercover investigation to test the security of radioactive materials at the US borders. They produced counterfeit documents, including NRC documents and a bill of lading, to support their investigators' reason for possessing radioactive sources.
* The investigators transported radioactive sources sufficient to manufacture a dirty bomb across the US-Canada and US-Mexico borders, using the counterfeit documents to pass through customs.
* In both cases, the CBP inspectors did not question the validity of the counterfeit documents and allowed the investigators to enter the country.
* The GAO found that suppliers are not required to exercise due diligence in determining the legitimacy of buyers' use for radioactive sources, and that the CBP inspectors did not use the Radiation Isotope Identifier Device (RIID) to verify the authenticity of the radioactive sources.
* The GAO recommended that the NRC and CBP work together to verify the authenticity of NRC materials documents, but the NRC officials disagreed with the GAO's assessment of the amount of radioactive material needed to produce a dirty bomb.
* The GAO believes that the ease with which they were able to purchase and transport radioactive sources highlights the potential risks of nuclear terrorism and the need for improved security measures to prevent the diversion of radioactive materials.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) relies on research laboratories, industry, and academia to develop new technologies, but historically has struggled to bring these technologies out of the lab environment and into real use. 
* To address this issue, DOD has established several "technology transition" programs, including the Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration (ACTD) program, the Foreign Comparative Testing (FCT) Program, and the Dual Use Science and Technology program, among others.
* The Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), the Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and the Quick Reaction Fund are three new transition programs established to speed the transition of technologies from the lab to the field. While these programs have shown some benefits, such as cost savings and improved performance, they have also faced challenges, including limited performance measures and inconsistent communication between program managers and stakeholders.
* To optimize the investment in these programs, the GAO recommends that DOD develop data and measures to support assessments of the performance of the three transition programs, as well as broader assessments of return on investment, and implement formal feedback mechanisms, including interim and after-action reporting, and project reviews if major deviations occur in a project.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Census Bureau is researching the feasibility of conducting targeted address canvassing for the 2020 Census, which involves verifying addresses in select areas that are more likely to require updates to the address list.
* The Bureau's 2020 Research and Testing and GSS-I schedules exhibit some characteristics of a reliable schedule, but important weaknesses remain, including a lack of comprehensiveness, well-constructed logic, and credibility.
* The Bureau has not taken advantage of some opportunities to use its schedules to reinforce roles or clarify responsibilities, and staff and managers have not been available and prepared to sufficiently construct and maintain the schedules.
* The Bureau has put in place a framework to support collaborative efforts following leading practices, including a strategic plan, memorandums of understanding, and various charters, but it is essential to ensure that these practices are continued and that collaboration is built into the schedule.
* The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Commerce and Undersecretary of Economic Affairs direct the U.S. Census Bureau to improve its scheduling practices in three areas: comprehensiveness, construction, and credibility, and that the Director of the U.S. Census Bureau initiate a robust workforce planning process for those working on schedules related to the Master Address File.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Clean Air Act, a comprehensive federal law, was passed in 1963 to regulate air pollution from stationary and mobile sources, and was substantially overhauled in 1970 to establish national ambient air quality standards.

• The Act was amended in 1977 and 1990, with the 1990 amendments incorporating market-based approaches to reduce emissions, such as cap-and-trade programs.

• The Clean Air Act requires states and local governments to carry out certain portions of the statute, including developing implementation plans to meet national standards set by EPA.

• EPA has set national ambient air quality standards for six major air pollutants: ozone, carbon monoxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, nitrogen dioxide, and lead.

• Despite progress in reducing emissions, large numbers of Americans continue to live in communities where pollution sometimes exceeds federal air quality standards.

• EPA has identified 452 actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, with about half of these actions related to Title III.

• EPA has completed most of the required actions, but missed deadlines for many of them, with an average delay of 24-25 months for Title I and III requirements.

• The delays were attributed to various factors, including the need for stakeholder review and involvement, prioritization of requirements, and competing demands on EPA staff.

• EPA has not yet completed 45 requirements related to Titles I and III, including rules to limit volatile organic compound emissions from consumer and commercial products and residual risk reviews for MACT standards.

• The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 have led to notable reductions in emissions of air pollutants, and EPA has applied the cap-and-trade model to several pollutants since 2000, but the agency's ability to apply this approach to hazardous air pollutants is unclear.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP) established the Girls Study Group in 2004 to identify effective programs for preventing and reducing girls' delinquency.
• The Study Group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs that specifically targeted preventing or responding to girls' delinquency.
• The group assessed the methodological quality of the studies using the What Works criteria developed by DOJ's Office of Justice Programs (OJP).
• The Study Group found that few girls' delinquency programs had been studied, and the available studies lacked conclusive evidence of effective programs.
• OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance to help programs prepare for evaluations of their effectiveness.
• The Study Group recommended additional, methodologically rigorous evaluations of girls' delinquency programs, training and technical assistance, and funding to support promising programs.
• OJJDP officials stated that they plan to issue a solicitation in fiscal year 2010 for funding to support evaluations of girls' delinquency programs.
• The Study Group's findings are intended to provide a foundation for moving ahead on a comprehensive program related to girls' delinquency.
• OJJDP has not developed a plan to meet its girls' delinquency goals, but plans to publish a proposed juvenile justice program plan in the Federal Register to solicit public feedback and comments.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) created the Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS) in 1991 to standardize DOD finance and accounting policies, procedures, and systems, and to eliminate duplicative and inefficient operations.

• Before 1991, each military service and defense agency had its own financial management structure, which led to inconsistencies and inefficiencies in financial management.

• DFAS was formed by consolidating the large finance and accounting centers of the military services and the Defense Logistics Agency under a single agency, and it assumed control of existing finance and accounting operations and personnel at the command and installation levels.

• By 1994, DFAS had assumed responsibility for many of the finance and accounting activities at 332 offices, and it had announced plans to consolidate these activities at a limited number of DFAS locations.

• DFAS is responsible for paying the salaries of 826,000 civilians and about 3 million military personnel, processing payments to about 2 million retirees and annuitants, and making payments to contractors for goods and services.

• DFAS also collects debts owed to DOD, including debts from military and civilian personnel and contractors, and it has a responsibility matrix with each military service to identify the specific activities that will be performed by DFAS and each service.

• The military services continue to perform some finance and accounting activities, such as managerial accounting, travel claim computation, and customer service, at most of the 332 installation-level finance offices.

• DOD's finance and accounting infrastructure has undergone significant changes since 1991, with a reduction in the number of finance and accounting systems used throughout DOD, and a focus on standardizing finance and accounting systems and processes.

</summary>

<summary>
* The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent agency with a decentralized structure to ensure that monetary policy decisions would be based on a broad economic perspective from all regions of the country. The Federal Reserve operates in a unique public and private structure, consisting of the Board of Governors, the 12 Reserve Banks, and the FOMC.
* The Reserve Banks derive income from various sources, maintain surplus accounts, and remit earnings in excess of expenses to Treasury. The surplus account is primarily intended to cushion against the possibility that total Reserve Bank capital would be depleted by losses incurred through Federal Reserve operations.
* Modifying the Reserve Bank stock ownership requirement could have a number of implications, including disrupting the Federal Reserve's public and private balance, diminishing Reserve Bank autonomy, and diminishing Federal Reserve financial independence. The Reserve Banks' ability to conduct banking operations could also be hindered if they were to become field offices of the Board of Governors.
* The Federal Reserve's financial independence is supported by its ability to generate income and maintain a capital base that is not funded at the discretion of the government. However, eliminating Reserve Bank stock could have implications for this goal, and dependence on Treasury for capitalization could diminish the financial independence of the Federal Reserve.
</summary>

<summary>

* The 1992 congressional testimony revealed that thieves turn stolen cars into money in three ways: by dismantling and selling car parts, obtaining a valid title and selling the car, or exporting the vehicle for sale abroad.
* The 1992 Act aimed to address these issues by establishing a task force to study motor vehicle theft and creating a new federal crime for armed car jacking.
* The Act also established the National Motor Vehicle Title Information System to enable states to check the validity of out-of-state titles and authorized grants up to 25% of a state's start-up costs.
* The National Stolen Passenger Motor Vehicle Information System (NSPMVIS) was required to be established by the Attorney General, containing vehicle identification numbers and other related data for stolen passenger motor vehicles and parts.
* The Motor Vehicle Titling, Registration, and Salvage Task Force recommended uniform definitions for salvage vehicles, titling and control methods, and duplicate title issuance, among other things.
* The National Stolen Auto Part Information System (NSAPIS) Federal Advisory Committee recommended that the National Insurance Crime Bureau (NICB) serve as the System Administrator for NSAPIS and that Congress enact legislation establishing an Oversight Committee to work with NICB.
* The implementation of the 1992 Act's provisions, including the National Motor Vehicle Title Information System and NSPMVIS, faced challenges such as funding, uniformity, and technological issues, and the effectiveness of parts marking and NSPMVIS was still being studied and evaluated.

</summary>

<summary>

* The distribution of and payment for prescription drugs involves interactions among multiple entities, including drug wholesalers, independent pharmacies, Pharmacy Service Administrative Organizations (PSAOs), and third-party payers and their Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs).
* Drug wholesalers purchase bulk quantities of drugs from pharmaceutical manufacturers and distribute them to pharmacies, including independent pharmacies, which may also purchase drugs directly from manufacturers.
* Independent pharmacies are a type of retail pharmacy that dispense medications to consumers and provide patient-care services, such as patient education, and are an important part of a wholesaler's customer portfolio.
* PSAOs provide a broad range of services to independent pharmacies, including negotiating contractual agreements, providing communication and help-desk services, and assisting with issues related to third-party payers and their PBMs.
* PSAOs may charge a monthly fee for a bundled set of services and separate fees for additional services, and most PSAOs are owned by wholesalers and independent pharmacy cooperatives.
* The owners of PSAOs may require member pharmacies to also use services from a separate non-PSAO line of business, but most do not, and pharmacies may choose to obtain PSAO services from their wholesaler or join another PSAO.
* PSAOs provide services intended to achieve administrative efficiencies for both independent pharmacies and third-party payers or their PBMs, including reducing the number of resources that PBMs must direct toward developing and maintaining relationships with multiple independent pharmacies.
* The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice (DOJ) are responsible for determining whether a particular collaborative arrangement between a PSAO and its member pharmacies may be unlawful and for enforcing applicable prohibitions.

</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government's 27 major departments and agencies have made progress in developing and using enterprise architectures, but most are not yet where they need to be relative to architecture content, use, and measurement. Many have fully satisfied a large percentage of the core elements across most of the stages, particularly those elements related to architecture governance. However, most departments and agencies are not yet where they need to be relative to architecture content, use, and measurement, and thus the federal government is not as well-positioned as it should be to realize the significant benefits that a well-managed architecture program can provide.
* The departments and agencies reported that they have collectively invested a total of $836 million to date on enterprise architecture development, with costs ranging from a low of $2 million by the Department of the Navy to a high of $433 million by the Department of Defense (DOD) on its Business Enterprise Architecture (BEA). The departments and agencies combined estimates of annual architecture maintenance costs is about $146 million.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was signed on January 19, 2006, and aims to promote economic growth and trade between the two countries. The agreement provides for the elimination of tariffs on most consumer and industrial goods, as well as increased market access for U.S. service suppliers and investors in Oman.
* The agreement has been criticized by some for its labor and environmental provisions, with concerns raised about the treatment of workers in Oman and the potential for sweatshop conditions. The U.S.-Oman FTA also includes a provision that could potentially allow foreign companies to own and operate U.S. port infrastructure, which has raised concerns about national security.
</summary>

<summary>
• Hate crimes are defined as criminal offenses motivated by bias against a person's race, religion, disability, ethnic/national origin, or sexual orientation, and have become a prominent concern among policymakers.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expanded the scope of hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability, and broadened federal jurisdiction to prosecute such crimes.
• The United States Supreme Court decision in United States v. Morrison raised questions about Congress's authority to expand hate crimes to cover violence based on gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.
• The commerce clause, section 5 of the 14th Amendment, and section 2 of the 13th and 15th Amendments are potential grants of power for Congress to proscribe hate crimes and enact civil rights legislation.
• The Court's decision in Morrison narrowed the "affects interstate commerce" category, making it difficult for Congress to regulate non-economic, violent criminal conduct based solely on its aggregate effect on interstate commerce.
• Hate crimes that involve interstate travel may still be within the commerce clause's reach, but the expansion of hate crime legislation may be suspect under this clause.
• Section 2 of the 13th Amendment may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation, as it proscribes slavery and involuntary servitude without reference to federal, state, or private action.
• Constitutional limits on hate crime legislation include the 1st Amendment's protection of free speech and the 6th Amendment's right to a jury trial, which may impact the constitutionality of hate crime statutes.
</summary>

<summary>
• The exchange rate policies of East Asian nations, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, have been a source of tension with the United States due to allegations of currency manipulation, which is prohibited by the International Monetary Fund's Articles of Agreement.
• The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires the Department of the Treasury to analyze the exchange rate policies of major trading partners, including those with significant bilateral trade surpluses and material current account surpluses.
• East Asian governments have adopted various exchange rate policies, ranging from a "free float" to a "managed float," with some countries, such as Hong Kong, maintaining a "fixed" or "pegged" exchange rate with the US dollar.
• The US Treasury's 2017 report identified six major trading partners, including China, Japan, and South Korea, as warranting close attention to their currency practices, but found that none met the criteria for currency manipulation.
• The report noted that China has a long history of engaging in large-scale foreign exchange intervention to resist renminbi appreciation, but has allowed the currency to appreciate in recent years, while Japan has not intervened in the foreign exchange market in five years.
• The debate over foreign exchange rate policies continues, with some arguing that a "free float" policy would reduce US trade deficits with East Asia, while others are skeptical about the effectiveness of such a policy and the potential impact on US industries.
</summary>

<summary>

* The role and effectiveness of U.S. ambassadors and Chiefs of Mission (COM) abroad have been a focus of congressional attention, particularly after the death of Ambassador Christopher Stevens in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
* COMs are the principal officers in charge of U.S. diplomatic missions to foreign countries, foreign territories, or international organizations, and are appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate.
* COMs serve as the President's personal representatives, leading diplomatic efforts and overseeing U.S. government activities in their country of assignment, with the primary exception of military operations.
* The State Department's 2010 Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review (QDDR) emphasized the need to equip COMs to better perform their role, casting them as chief executive officers (CEOs) of multi-agency missions.
* COM authority is explained primarily in the Foreign Service Act of 1980, as amended (FSA 1980), and is shaped by executive branch directives, including executive orders and presidential directives.
* COM authority extends to executive branch agencies, but not generally to the legislative and judicial branches, and is limited to coordinating and supervising U.S. government activities in a host country.
* COMs have authority over personnel, including full-time, non-full-time, non-permanent, and non-direct-hire personnel operating in a foreign country or at a U.S. mission abroad, and must approve entry into a host country by all personnel.
* COMs do not have authority over GCCs, but are expected to maintain a cooperative relationship with them, and may delegate operational responsibilities to the heads of agencies.
* The effectiveness of COM authority in practice has been questioned, with some analysts raising concerns about the ability of COMs to manage their embassies and exert their authority, and recommending steps to improve COM performance, including providing COMs with the support of officials in Washington and recognizing their role with respect to other agencies.

</summary>

<summary>
* China's economy is heavily dependent on global trade and investment flows, with exports contributing to one-third of its GDP growth in 2007.
* The country's exports of goods and services as a share of GDP rose from 9.1% in 1985 to 37.8% in 2008.
* China's foreign trade sector employs over 80 million people, with 28 million working in foreign-invested enterprises.
* Foreign direct investment (FDI) flows to China have been a major factor behind its productivity gains and rapid economic growth, with FDI flows totaling $75 billion in 2007 and $92 billion in 2008.
* The current global economic slowdown has had a significant negative impact on China's export sector and industries that depend on FDI flows, leading to a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2008 and early 2009.
* China's government has taken steps to respond to the global financial crisis, including cutting interest rates, boosting bank lending, and implementing a stimulus package worth 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion) to finance infrastructure projects and other initiatives.
* The stimulus package has helped to boost economic growth, with GDP growing by 7.9% in the second quarter of 2009, but analysts have raised concerns about the long-term sustainability of the recovery and the potential for a sharp rise in non-performing loans on the balance sheets of China's major banks.
* China's large holdings of U.S. securities, estimated to be around $1,205 billion as of June 2008, have raised concerns about the potential risks of investing in U.S. assets, particularly in the context of the global financial crisis.
</summary>

<summary>
• The national mining and minerals policy fosters private enterprise in the development of domestic mining, minerals, metal, and mineral reclamation industries, and the orderly and economic development of domestic mineral resources, reserves, and reclamation of metals and minerals.
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages most federal mineral development and is responsible for implementing this policy, while the Forest Service manages federal lands in the National Forest System (NFS) and authorizes mineral development on NFS lands.
• The Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA) authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to issue permits for exploration and to lease lands containing oil and gas and other defense-related minerals, and the Secretary must apply "multiple use" and "sustained yield" principles when developing Resource Management Plans (RMPs).
• The competitive leasing process involves posting a list of lands available for leasing, submitting nominations for parcels to be auctioned, and holding a quarterly oral auction with a national minimum acceptable bid of $2 per acre.
• Noncompetitive leasing is available for two years after the competitive bidding auction, and the first qualified person who applies for a noncompetitive lease and pays the $75 application fee is entitled to receive the lease without having to competitively bid.
• The Secretary of the Interior has the power to waive, suspend, or reduce rentals and royalties under certain conditions, and the Secretary must conduct an internal review of Federal onshore oil and gas leasing and permitting practices and submit a report to Congress detailing steps to improve the process.
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 requires the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding regarding issues such as the establishment of procedures to ensure timely processing of oil and gas lease applications, surface use plans of operation, and Applications for a Permit to Drill (APDs).
</summary>

<summary>
* Policymakers are considering reforming or limiting itemized tax deductions for individuals to increase federal tax revenue, simplify the tax code, and reduce incentives for inefficient economic behavior. However, some argue that limits on deductions could have adverse economic effects or change the distributional burden of the federal income tax code.
* Data analysis from the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) Statistics of Income (SOI) shows that in 2014, 30% of tax filers chose to itemize their deductions, with higher-income individuals more likely to itemize and claim larger deductions. The majority of itemizers had incomes less than $100,000, but higher-income individuals claimed a larger share of total itemized deductions.
* The Joint Committee on Taxation's (JCT) estimates show that the top four itemized deductions that contribute most to annual tax expenditures in FY2018 are the deduction for state and local income or sales taxes, home mortgage interest, charitable gifts, and real estate taxes. These deductions account for 17.8% of the approximately $1.36 trillion in net individual tax expenditures.
* Proposals to reform or limit itemized deductions include a flat, dollar-value cap or percentage-of-income cap on total deductions, a limit on the tax rate at which deductions can be valued, and converting deductions into credits. However, the form and structure of a limit on itemized deductions could affect which deductions a tax filer might claim and the extent to which it increases revenue.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Pacific Islands region is strategically important, encompassing U.S. Pacific territories, and presents Congress with diverse policy issues, including climate change, economic development, and regional security. The region includes 14 sovereign states with approximately 9 million people, and the United States has economic interests, particularly in fishing.
• The United States provides foreign assistance to Pacific Island countries, which are vulnerable to climate change, and has a long-standing relationship with the region, including the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The U.S. government administers foreign assistance through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and has partnered with Pacific Islands regional organizations to address climate change.
• China has become a major source of foreign assistance in the region, providing $150 million in foreign assistance per year on average during the past decade, and has economic interests in sectors such as energy production, mining, fisheries, timber, agriculture, and tourism. However, some observers have criticized Chinese assistance, arguing that some infrastructure projects are poor in quality and that some Chinese loans and aid activities lack transparency and exacerbate corruption.
• The Pacific Islands region faces significant environmental challenges, including climate change, sea level rise, ocean acidification, and overfishing, which can have adverse effects on agriculture, drinking water supplies, fisheries, and tourism. The region's leaders have sought international support for helping them to cope with the impacts of climate change, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and increase renewable energy use and energy efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction, and federal agencies are required to use their existing authorities to further the purposes of the act.
* The exemption process under the ESA allows for federal agencies to seek exemptions from the act's restrictions, but this process is rarely used and is subject to strict criteria and requirements, including a formal hearing and a report from the Secretary.
* The exemption process is used to balance the national interest in protecting listed species against the national interest in proceeding with an important federal project, and the Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews applications for exemptions and determines whether to grant an exemption.
* The ESC can grant an exemption if it determines that there are no reasonable and prudent alternatives to the agency action, the benefits of the action clearly outweigh the benefits of alternative courses of action, and the action is in the public interest and of regional or national significance.
* The exemption process is complex and can take up to 280 days, and even if an exemption is granted, the burden of conservation and recovery may fall more heavily on other areas that the species inhabits or on other resources that the species requires, and other laws may still be in play, leading to ongoing conflicts.
</summary>

<summary>
• The tax treatment of capital losses has been a topic of debate in Congress, with various proposals to increase the limit on capital losses that can be deducted against ordinary income. However, increasing the limit without addressing the asymmetry between the tax treatment of capital gains and losses could expand opportunities to game the system and benefit high-income individuals.
• Achieving full symmetry in the system requires accounting for the tax rate differential between short and long-term gains and losses, which could be achieved through a netting process that requires $2 of net long-term losses to offset $1 of short-term gain or ordinary income, or by instituting a tax credit of 15% for capital losses.
</summary>

<summary>

* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing, aiming to mitigate labor-related obstructions to the free flow of commerce.
* The NLRA does not apply to all individuals employed by an employer, but only to "employees," excluding supervisors as defined by the Act.
* The term "supervisor" under the NLRA includes any individual with the authority to perform specified functions, requiring the use of independent judgment and not merely routine or clerical.
* In NLRB v. Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the U.S. Supreme Court established a three-part test for determining supervisory status, including the exercise of authority, independent judgment, and the interest of the employer.
* The NLRB has revisited the issue of supervisory status in Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., defining the terms "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment" as used in section 2(11) of the NLRA.
* The NLRA prohibits certain misconduct by both employers and unions that interferes with the right to engage in collective bargaining, including the use or threatened use of violence, verbal threats, and coercion.
* Employers may make antiunion, but noncoercive, speeches to their employees on company time and property without allowing a union an equal opportunity to reply, but last-minute speeches are prohibited within 24 hours before an election.
* The NLRA does not require employers to allow the distribution of union literature on their premises, but access may be permitted if the employer's location and the employees' residences place them beyond the reach of reasonable union efforts to communicate with them.

</summary>

<summary>

* The banking system plays a crucial role in the financial system by connecting borrowers to savers and allocating capital across the economy, but it is also inherently risky and can generate devastating losses if not properly regulated. A regulatory system has developed over time to foster the benefits of banking while limiting risks, and both banks and regulation have coevolved as market conditions have changed and different risks have emerged.
* The 2008-2009 financial crisis led to significant changes in banking regulation, including the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, which aimed to strengthen regulation and address risks. However, some observers have raised concerns that the potential benefits of the regulatory changes are outweighed by the potential costs, such as reduced credit availability and slower economic growth.
* The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) was established under the Dodd-Frank Act to regulate consumer financial products and services, but its structure and authorities have been the subject of controversy, with some arguing that it is too focused on consumer protection and restricts credit availability.
* The "too big to fail" (TBTF) problem refers to the issue of large, complex, and interconnected financial institutions that are perceived to be too important to fail, and which may take on excessive risk and enjoy unfair advantages in the market for funding. Enhanced prudential regulation and the Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA) were established to address this problem, but critics argue that these measures may not be effective and could even exacerbate the moral hazard problem.
* The regulatory burden on community banks is a significant issue, with some arguing that the costs of regulation outweigh the benefits and that small banks are being driven out of business by excessive regulatory requirements. Others argue that community banks are an important source of credit for local communities and that regulation should be tailored to reduce the burden on small banks.

</summary>

<summary>
* The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) was signed into law on December 29, 2007, to extend funding for these programs and make various changes to their operations.
* The Act suspended the Medicare physician payment cut scheduled to take effect in 2008 and provided SCHIP funding through March 2009.
* It also made changes to the Medicare physician payment update formula, redistributing unspent FY2006 funds to states with shortfalls, and providing additional funding to shortfall states and territories.
* The Act extended various expiring provisions and programs, including Medicare Advantage plans, Medicaid payments and programs, and the State Health Insurance Assistance Programs.
* It also included funding for miscellaneous activities, such as research into the prevention of Type I diabetes and grants for the prevention and treatment of diabetes among American Indians and Alaskan Natives.
* The Act included offsets to pay for the provisions, including a reduction in federal payments for the Medicare Advantage stabilization fund and changes to the Medicare payment system for certain services.
* The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the Act would result in a net savings to the federal government of $100 million between FY2008 and FY2012.
</summary>

<summary>
* The House of Representatives has rules governing the authority and operations of its committees and subcommittees, which are outlined in Rules X-XIII. These rules cover topics such as committee establishment, assignments, hearings, markups, reporting, oversight, funding, staff, and travel, as well as the adoption and publication of committee rules and the availability of committee records.
* Committees are required to adopt written rules of procedure, which must be consistent with House rules and applicable provisions of law. Committees are also responsible for conducting oversight and investigations, and must submit reports on their activities to the House. Additionally, committees must follow specific rules and procedures for hearings, markups, and other meetings, and must ensure that their staff and records are properly managed and maintained.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a 10-member grouping of nations with a combined population of 580 million and an annual gross domestic product (GDP) of around $1.5 trillion. It was established in 1967 to foster regional dialogue and has grown into one of the world's largest regional fora.
* The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, including maritime security, democracy and human rights, liberal trade and investment regimes, counterterrorism, and combating illegal trafficking. However, the US has been perceived as neglectful of ASEAN and Southeast Asia, particularly under the Bush Administration.
* The Obama Administration has taken steps to engage with ASEAN, including appointing an ambassador to ASEAN, providing assistance to the ASEAN Secretariat, and launching the US-ASEAN Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA). The US has also acceded to ASEAN's Treaty of Amity and Cooperation (TAC) and participated in the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF).
* ASEAN has been pursuing ways to expedite closer economic ties among its 10 member nations, with the goal of creating an ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) by 2015. The US is the only major power in the region that has not agreed to a formal free trade agreement (FTA) with ASEAN.
* ASEAN's relations with Burma (Myanmar) have been a challenge, with the organization adopting a policy of "constructive engagement" towards the country. However, the new ASEAN Charter has signaled a greater willingness to address issues such as human rights and democracy, and ASEAN has expressed its disappointment at Burma's human rights record.
* The US provides significant assistance to ASEAN, including funding for trade facilitation, counterterrorism, security sector reform, and the environment. The US is also engaged economically with ASEAN, being the fourth-largest trading partner and a major source of foreign direct investment (FDI).
</summary>

<summary>
* The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979, and Cuba has remained on the list since 1982.
* The list currently includes four other countries: Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria, and being listed restricts trade benefits, foreign aid, and other benefits.
* A country's retention on the list can be rescinded in two ways: through a presidential report to Congress or by submitting a report justifying the recision.
* Three countries have been removed from the list: South Yemen, Iraq, and Libya, with Iraq being added and removed twice.
* Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its support for terrorist groups in Latin America, including the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia.
* The State Department has continued to assert that Cuba supports terrorism, citing its hosting of members of foreign terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice.
* Critics argue that Cuba's presence on the list is a holdover of the Cold War and that domestic political considerations keep it on the list, diverting U.S. attention from serious terrorist threats.
* There is ongoing debate about the level of terrorist activity by countries on the list, with some suggesting a tiered approach to sanctions and others advocating for strong sanctions against any level of support for terrorism.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a tax calculation that provides for an alternative tax calculation on a broader tax base than the regular tax, with a higher exemption for joint returns ($45,000) and single returns ($33,750), and a tax rate of 26% for the first $175,000 and 28% for the remainder.
• The AMT has been growing in importance, with the number of taxpayers covered increasing from 140,000 in 1987 to 9 million in 2009, and the share of taxpayers on the AMT rising from 1/10 of 1% to 6.3% of all tax returns filed.
• The AMT interacts with tax cuts, causing some taxpayers to be shifted to the AMT and reducing the effectiveness of tax cuts, particularly for joint returns with higher incomes and more dependents.
• Indexing the AMT exemptions to inflation would cost $13.9 billion by 2008, while eliminating the credit limit provision would cost $1 billion currently but $26 billion by 2009, and eliminating the AMT altogether would be a more complex issue.
• The AMT has been considered a potential problem for some time, and its importance increases with tax cuts, causing not all taxpayers to receive the full amount, or even any, tax cut, and increasing the complications for taxpayers in filing their tax return.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate draft bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six small related agencies. The THUD appropriations bill is divided into four titles: Title I funds DOT, Title II funds HUD, Title III funds a collection of agencies involved in transportation or housing and community development, and Title IV sets out general provisions applicable to the bill.
• The discretionary funding provided for THUD is typically around half of the total funding provided in the bill, with the remainder made up of DOT's mandatory contract authority. The largest source of budgetary savings for the THUD subcommittees is generally HUD's FHA insurance fund, which can provide significant offsets to discretionary funding.
• The FY2018 THUD appropriations bill saw various proposals and funding levels from the Trump Administration, the House, and the Senate. The House-passed bill would provide a reduction of less than 1% from FY2017, while the Senate-reported bill would provide a 2% increase for DOT and a 4% increase for HUD. The Senate bill also included several policy provisions different from those in the House bill.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. and India have a "global partnership" established in 2005, but India's close relations with Iran pose a challenge to this partnership, particularly in the areas of energy and non-proliferation.
* India and Iran have a long history of positive relations, dating back to the interactions of Persian and Indus Valley civilizations, and have a "strategic partnership" since 2003, with cooperation in energy, trade, and defense.
* The U.S. has expressed concerns about India's defense relations with Iran, including the proposed construction of a pipeline to deliver Iranian natural gas to India through Pakistan, which the Bush Administration opposes.
* India has sought to maintain a balance between its relations with the U.S. and Iran, and has voted with the U.S. on several occasions, including at the IAEA, but has also maintained its traditional ties with Iran and has not abandoned its relationship with Tehran.
* India has imposed restrictions on nuclear-related exports to Iran in accordance with U.N. Security Council Resolution 1737, and has also taken steps to bring its Iran policy into closer alignment with that of the U.S.
* Despite these efforts, India's relations with Iran remain a point of contention between India and the U.S., with some in Congress voicing concerns about India's defense relations with Iran and the potential for India to assist Iran's nuclear program.
</summary>

<summary>
• The US dairy industry is considering imposing new import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) to prevent unlimited imports and raise milk prices for dairy farmers, but this move could increase costs for dairy processors and result in higher retail food prices. 
• The proposed legislation, such as the Milk Import Tariff Equity Act, would introduce tariff-rate quotas (TRQs) for MPCs and casein/caseinates, which could lead to compensation negotiations with major suppliers under the World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, potentially resulting in a compensation of around $500 million.
</summary>

<summary>
* In October 2000, a coalition of democratic parties defeated Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in presidential elections, marking the beginning of a transition toward Western democratic and free market standards in Serbia.
* Serbia has made progress in holding free and fair elections, adopting a new constitution, and integrating into the European Union, but still faces challenges such as organized crime, high-level corruption, and economic decline.
* The country's relations with Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, remain a major challenge, with Serbia refusing to recognize Kosovo's independence and the EU pressing Serbia to normalize relations with Kosovo.
* In 2012, Tomislav Nikolic, a former nationalist, was elected president of Serbia, and a coalition government was formed between the Progressives and the Socialists, with Ivica Dacic as prime minister.
* Serbia's economy has been affected by the global economic crisis, with a decline in foreign direct investment and a rise in unemployment, but the government has taken steps to boost its popularity by launching an anti-corruption drive.
* Serbia has sought a precautionary loan arrangement with the IMF and has been successful in borrowing in the Eurobond market, but the IMF wants Serbia to make more credible efforts to cut its budget deficit and public debt.
* The EU has recommended that Serbia be granted a starting date for its EU membership talks, but the implementation of the Kosovo-Serbia agreements and the dismantling of Serbian security structures in Kosovo remain key challenges to Serbia's EU membership prospects.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term, including Florida v. Jardines, which involved a dog sniff at the front door of a suspected grow house, and Florida v. Harris, which related to whether an alert by a trained drug-detection dog is sufficient to establish probable cause for a search of a vehicle.
* In Florida v. Jardines, the Court held that a dog sniff at the front door of a private home is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause, and that the use of a trained narcotics-detection dog on the front porch of a home is a physical intrusion on constitutionally protected areas.
* In Florida v. Harris, the Court held that a trained drug-detection dog's positive reaction is sufficient to establish probable cause for a search, but that the state must present evidence of the dog's reliability, including training and certification records, field performance records, and evidence of the officer's experience and training.
* In Bailey v. United States, the Court held that the detention of an individual who has just left premises to be searched under warrant is permissible only if the detention occurs in the immediate vicinity of the premises, and that the police must weigh the factors of officer safety, preservation of evidence, and prevention of flight in determining whether to detain an individual.
* In Missouri v. McNeely, the Court held that the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream does not constitute a per se exigency that justifies an exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases, and that the existence of an exception must be determined on a case-by-case basis, taking into account all the relevant facts presented in a specific case.
</summary>

<summary>
• The federal government first supported a program for energy storage and electric power system technology during the 1970s, focusing mainly on energy storage to even out variable power production from wind and solar technologies.
• The advancement of computer capacity, miniaturization, and industrial controls has expanded the ability of grid operators to monitor and control electric power flows, but has also made the grid vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions.
• The nation's energy infrastructure is diverse, including a variety of transmission and distribution system network structures, operating models, and hardware and software, making it complicated to coordinate security and resilience.
• Key challenges facing the electric power industry include a changing power generation mix, replacing aging infrastructure, modernizing and securing communication networks, and accommodating new end-use technologies.
• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is charged with supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure through research and development, demonstration projects, partnerships, and emergency preparedness and response.
• OE's mission is guided by two key DOE planning documents: the Quadrennial Technology Review and the Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan, which aim to achieve a 10% reduction in the economic costs of power outages, a 33% decrease in the cost of reserve margins, and a 50% decrease in the net integration costs of distributed energy resources by 2025.
• OE programs are aligned with the Obama Administration's priorities, including grid modernization, cybersecurity, and energy innovation, and have received significant funding boosts, including $4.5 billion from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.
• The FY2017 OE request sought funding changes for several programs, including the creation of three new programs: State Distribution-Level Reform, State Energy Assurance, and Grid Institute, and proposed to fund three to four new highly leveraged, cost-shared demonstrations with states.
• The FY2017 request also sought to continue crosscutting programs that coordinate across the department and to employ DOE's full ability to address national energy, environmental, and security challenges, with a total of $206 million in funding for OE, the same amount as the FY2016 appropriation.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) was enacted in 1986 to guide the creation of memorials in the District of Columbia, with the goal of preserving the integrity of the comprehensive design of the L'Enfant and McMillan plans for the Nation's Capital.
* Prior to the CWA, Congress had authorized over 100 memorials in the District of Columbia, but there were no statutory criteria for authorizing commemorative works, and Congress had to establish how sponsoring organizations would choose site locations and approve memorial designs.
* The CWA defines a commemorative work as "any statue, monument, sculpture, memorial, plaque, inscription, or other structure of landscape feature" designed to perpetuate the memory of an individual, group, event, or other significant element of American history.
* The CWA divides the District of Columbia and its environs into three sections for the placement of memorials: the Reserve, Area I, and Area II, with different standards for memorial placement in each area.
* The Reserve is a "no-build zone" on the National Mall, where new commemorative works are prohibited, except for those authorized prior to the enactment of the CWA.
* Area I is reserved for commemorative works of "preeminent historical and lasting significance to the United States," and requires congressional approval for placement.
* Area II is reserved for "subjects of lasting historical significance to the American people," and does not require congressional approval for placement.
* The process for establishing a memorial in the District of Columbia involves 24 steps, including seeking National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission assistance, introducing authorizing legislation, site selection, design approval, fundraising, and construction.
* The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission, the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, the National Capital Planning Commission, the District of Columbia Historic Preservation Office, and the American Battle Monuments Commission are all involved in the memorial creation process in the District of Columbia.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Senate Finance Committee approved the America's Healthy Future Act of 2009 on October 13, 2009, which aimed to reform the private health insurance market and provide health insurance coverage to more Americans.
* The bill required individuals to maintain health insurance and certain employers with more than 50 employees to provide insurance or pay a tax, with some exceptions.
* The bill introduced market reforms, including modified community rating and guaranteed issue and insurance renewal, and required insurers to offer coverage to individuals with pre-existing conditions.
* The bill established a new health insurance exchange, where individuals and small businesses could purchase private health insurance plans, and provided subsidies to help low-income individuals and families afford health insurance.
* The bill required health insurance plans to provide essential benefits, including hospitalization, outpatient services, and preventive care, and prohibited plans from imposing annual or lifetime limits on coverage.
* The bill allowed states to establish basic health plans for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid and provided funding to states to support these plans.
* The bill imposed an excise tax on high-cost employer-sponsored health insurance and an annual fee on health insurance providers, and limited the deductibility of compensation for health insurance executives.
* The bill also modified tax-advantaged accounts, including flexible spending accounts (FSAs), health savings accounts (HSAs), and health reimbursement accounts (HRAs), and restricted the definition of qualified medical expenses.
* The bill aimed to raise $304 billion in revenues over 10 years through these revenue provisions, which would be used to pay for expanded health insurance coverage.

</summary>

<summary>
• High risk health insurance pools (HRPs) are programs established by 35 states to provide health coverage to individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market, primarily due to preexisting health conditions.
• HRPs generally cover people who have been denied coverage, received quotes with higher premiums, or received offers with permanent exclusion of preexisting health conditions in the individual market.
• State high risk pools tend to enroll a small percentage of the uninsured, with approximately 200,000 individuals enrolled in 2008, but the Government Accountability Office estimated that nearly 4 million additional persons were potentially eligible for enrollment.
• The federal government has provided financial assistance to states through grants to support the establishment and operation of high risk pools, with a total of $49,127,000 allocated in 2008 and $75,000,000 in 2009.
• The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a temporary high risk pool program prior to 2014, and 29 states and DC contracted to operate their own HRPs, while HHS administers the HRPs in 21 states under the Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan (PCIP) name.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) program was created in 1951 by President Truman to provide airlift support to the Department of Defense (DOD) in times of crisis. The program allows DOD to tap into the commercial airline industry's capacity to transport passengers and cargo, providing a cost-effective alternative to maintaining a large organic airlift fleet.
* The CRAF program has undergone changes and updates over the years, with recent legislation and studies examining its viability and potential improvements. The FY2008 National Defense Authorization Act required a comprehensive assessment of CRAF's viability, and a study on the size and mix of the airlift force to meet future military requirements.
* The CRAF program has been activated on two separate occasions, during Operations Desert Shield/Storm and Operation Iraqi Freedom, and has provided significant airlift support to DOD. The program's benefits and opportunities for both DOD and the U.S. airline industry are discussed, as well as potential changes and challenges facing the program, including the impact of rising fuel prices and foreign investment in U.S. airlines.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies.
* The NTIA has various responsibilities, including overseeing the transfer of radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, administering grant programs, and collaborating with other agencies to develop Internet policy and manage spectrum use.
* The NTIA is working to increase spectrum capacity for mobile broadband by 500 MHz, and has produced a 10-year plan and timetable to identify bands of spectrum that might be available for commercial wireless broadband service.
* The NTIA is also involved in international spectrum allocation agreements, and works with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the Department of State to negotiate international treaties on spectrum use through the World Radio Conference (WRC).
</summary>

<summary>
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-58) was signed by President Bush on August 8, 2005, and included major provisions such as tax incentives for domestic energy production and energy efficiency, a mandate to double the nation's use of biofuels, and authorization of federal energy research and development programs.
• The Act also included provisions related to electricity, including the creation of a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC)-certified Electric Reliability Organization (ERO) to develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection.
• The Act also addressed issues related to the siting of interstate electric transmission facilities, including a study of electric transmission congestion and the designation of geographic areas as congested, as well as the issuance of construction permits and the exercise of eminent domain authority.
• The Act also included provisions related to third-party finance, advanced transmission technologies, and open nondiscriminatory access, including the authorization of FERC to require unregulated transmitting utilities to charge rates comparable to those charged to themselves.
• The Act also repealed the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA) and made changes to the Federal Power Act, including the creation of a new definition of "electric utility" and the addition of new definitions for terms such as "electric cooperative" and "regional transmission organization".
</summary>

<summary>
• The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) was enacted in 1936 to create a market atmosphere where small businesses could compete effectively with larger rivals, particularly in the grocery store industry.
• The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality," with some exceptions, such as the "meeting competition" defense and the "cost justified" defense.
• The Nonprofit Institutions Act (1938) created a broad exemption from the general price-discrimination prohibition for purchases made by nonprofit institutions, such as schools, hospitals, and charitable organizations, for their own use.
• The Supreme Court has interpreted the scope of the nonprofit exemption in several cases, including Abbott Laboratories v. Portland Retail Druggists Association, Inc. (1976) and Jefferson County Pharmaceutical Ass'n., Inc. v. Abbott Laboratories (1983), which established that purchases made by nonprofit hospitals for resale or for use in retail competition are subject to the strictures of the act.
• Health maintenance organizations (HMOs) have been held to be eligible institutions under the Nonprofit Institutions Act, and their purchases of drugs for resale to members are considered "own use" within the meaning of the act.
• The Robinson-Patman Act has been criticized for limiting discounting and causing consumers to pay higher prices, and the Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended its repeal in 2007, although no legislation has been introduced to modify or repeal the statute since then.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Obama Administration has faced significant scrutiny for its use of enforcement discretion, which involves limiting or delaying the enforcement of specific provisions of federal law, often based on practical or policy considerations.

• The Administration has justified its inaction as consistent with a proper exercise of enforcement discretion, a legal doctrine that generally shields executive branch enforcement decisions from judicial review.

• The Department of Justice (DOJ) has cited prosecutorial discretion as the basis for its efforts to curtail the enforcement of the federal Controlled Substances Act (CSA) in states that have adopted medical and recreational marijuana legalization initiatives.

• The Secretary of Homeland Security relied on the doctrine of administrative enforcement discretion in a 2012 memorandum setting forth guidelines on how to enforce the Nation's immigration laws against certain young people who were brought to the country as children.

• The Administration has also utilized enforcement discretion to justify delays in the enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), including the law's employer mandate and minimum coverage requirements.

• The Take Care Clause of the Constitution, which requires the President to "take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed," has been interpreted as imposing a duty on the President to ensure that executive branch officials obey Congress's commands.

• The Supreme Court has consistently held that the President has no authority to direct the execution of the law, and that the Take Care Clause does not provide the President with the authority to frustrate legal requirements imposed by law.

• Congress may restrain administrative enforcement discretion by statute, and enact laws that reduce agency officials' freedom in making enforcement and nonenforcement decisions.

• The Supreme Court has established that Congress may set "substantive priorities" for an agency to follow in exercising its enforcement power, and that Congress has the authority to establish factors for consideration in making enforcement decisions, which would be within the judicial authority to ensure executive compliance with those explicit statutory requirements.

</summary>

<summary>

• In 2013, the official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5%, a statistically significant drop from 15.0% in 2012, and the first drop since 2006. The number of people living below the poverty line remained statistically unchanged at 45.3 million.
