• Poverty rates tend to follow the economic cycle, increasing during recessions and decreasing during periods of sustained economic growth. The poverty rate increased over the past decade due to two economic recessions.

• The poverty rate among non-aged adults (18-64) was 13.6% in 2013, statistically unchanged from the prior three years. The poverty rate for children fell from 21.3% in 2012 to 19.5% in 2013, but remains above its pre-recession low of 16.9%.

• The poverty rate among the aged (65 and over) was 9.5% in 2013, statistically unchanged from 2012. However, the number of aged poor increased by 305,000 from 2012 to 2013.

• The Census Bureau's poverty thresholds are based on a minimal standard of food consumption from the 1950s and have not been adjusted for changes in living standards. The official poverty measure ignores non-cash benefits, taxes, and necessary expenses, which are included in the Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM).

• The SPM, developed by the Census Bureau and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, provides a more comprehensive measure of poverty by including in-kind benefits, refundable tax credits, and necessary expenses. The SPM poverty rate was 15.5% in 2013, higher than the official poverty rate of 14.5%.

• The SPM yields a different picture of poverty rates among different groups, with higher poverty rates among the aged and lower poverty rates among children compared to the official poverty measure. The SPM also highlights the importance of medical expenses, work-related expenses, and child care costs in determining poverty status.</summary>

<summary>

* The U.S. agricultural sector relies heavily on exports, with estimates suggesting that they account for about 20% of total U.S. agricultural production.
* The U.S. farm policy is subject to intense scrutiny due to its potential to diminish the success of future multilateral negotiations and its compliance with current WTO rules.
* The farm bill, which is renewed every five or six years, has been a part of U.S. farm legislation since the 1930s and involves modifications or replacements of existing farm programs.
* The Agricultural Act of 2014 made several substantial changes to the previous farm safety net and most of its agricultural provisions will not expire until September 30, 2018.
* The World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements, including the Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) and the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM), govern domestic agricultural support and trade.
* The AoA categorizes and restricts agricultural domestic support programs according to their potential to distort commercial markets, with green box programs being minimally or non-trade distorting and amber box programs being the most market-distorting.
* The United States is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays, and the most recent U.S. notification to the WTO of domestic farm program spending was made on December 8, 2014.
* The U.S. farm programs are also subject to SCM rules, which detail rules for determining when a subsidy is "prohibited" or "actionable" and can result in significant market distortions.

</summary>

<summary>
• The campus-based programs, including the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG) program, the Federal Work-Study (FWS) program, and the Federal Perkins Loan program, are collectively referred to as the "campus-based" programs and are authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA).
• The campus-based programs are considered unique because federal funds are awarded directly to institutions of higher education (IHEs) that administer the programs and provide institutional funds to match the federal funds they receive.
• The programs' authorizations of appropriations expired at the end of FY2015, but the FSEOG and FWS programs have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills, while the Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017.
• The campus-based programs have come to play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort, with 2% of the approximately $125 billion of federal aid made available to students through programs authorized under the HEA in FY2016 coming from the campus-based aid programs.
• The HEA authorizes most of the federal programs that provide direct financial aid to postsecondary students, and lawmakers may consider reauthorization of the HEA, which may include issues related to the campus-based programs.
• The campus-based programs were among the first of the federally funded student aid programs, with the Federal Perkins Loan program being the oldest, originally enacted under Title II of the National Defense Education Act of 1958 (NDEA).
• The FWS program was originally authorized as the College Work Study program under the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 (P.L. 88-452), and the FSEOG program was authorized as Education Opportunity Grants under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
• The campus-based programs have undergone several notable revisions since their original enactment, including changes to the institutional match, loan cancellation and deferment provisions, and the annual loan limit on Perkins Loans.
• Issues related to the campus-based programs that may be considered during reauthorization include the extent to which they serve a distinctive purpose, the formula for allocating funds to institutions, and whether the programs should be eliminated or consolidated with other federal student aid programs.
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has been increasingly involved in helping to prevent and recover missing adults, particularly those with cognitive or physical disabilities, and has proposed measures to assist in recovery efforts, including a grant program to encourage states to establish, expand, and coordinate alert systems for vulnerable adults.
* Currently, 11 states have implemented alert systems for missing adults, which are similar to AMBER Alert systems for abducted children but target adults who are vulnerable to going missing due to cognitive or mental impairment, developmental or physical disabilities, and certain mental health conditions.
* The federal government could play a role in further developing state alert systems by providing funding, technical support, and training, as well as assisting in the development of formal agreements or protocols for the use of interstate alerts and coordinating efforts when a missing individual is believed to have crossed state lines.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) FY2017 appropriations report describes and analyzes annual appropriations for DHS, comparing the enacted FY2016 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, the Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and the appropriations measures developed in response. The report also provides a list of Congressional Research Service (CRS) policy experts and identifies additional informational resources on DHS appropriations.
* The report discusses various budgetary concepts, including budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, and offsetting collections. It also explains the 302(a) and 302(b) allocations, the Budget Control Act, discretionary spending caps, and adjustments, and provides a detailed breakdown of the FY2017 appropriations for DHS, including the Departmental Management and Operations, Security, Enforcement, and Investigations, Protection, Preparedness, Response, and Recovery, and Research and Development, Training, and Services titles.
</summary>

<summary>

• The September 11, 2001, attacks drew attention to the security of the nation's water supply and water quality infrastructure, which has long been recognized as potentially vulnerable to terrorist attacks.

• The federal government has ownership responsibility for hundreds of dams and diversion structures, but the vast majority of the nation's water infrastructure is privately owned or owned by non-federal units of government.

• The potential for terrorism is not new, as FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover wrote in 1941 that water supply facilities offer a particularly vulnerable point of attack to foreign agents.

• Water infrastructure systems are highly linked with other infrastructure systems, such as electric power and transportation, making security of all of them an issue of concern.

• The federal government has implemented various security measures since 9/11, including closing visitor facilities at dams and implementing additional security measures at Reclamation facilities.

• Drinking water and wastewater utilities have also taken steps to improve security, including conducting vulnerability assessments and implementing physical security enhancements.

• The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has played a key role in water security efforts, including establishing a partnership with the American Metropolitan Water Association and American Water Works Association to safeguard water supplies from terrorist acts.

• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has also been involved in water security efforts, including issuing a National Infrastructure Protection Plan (NIPP) and establishing the Critical Infrastructure Partnership Advisory Council (CIPAC) to coordinate federal infrastructure protection programs with similar activities of the private sector.

• The cost of additional protections and how to pay for them are issues of great interest, and policymakers continue to consider resource needs and how to direct them at public and private sector priorities.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV) reauthorizes and amends the Perkins Act, which provides support for career and technical education in the United States.
• Perkins IV retains the overall purpose of the act, making only technical changes, and authorizes "such sums as may be necessary" for FY2007-FY2012 for Perkins Act programs and activities.
• The act includes several changes to the state allotment formula, including the distribution of "additional funds" above the amount allotted to states for FY2006, and modifies the substate formula for distribution of funds for secondary school CTE programs.
• Perkins IV strengthens and changes accountability requirements, including the specification of separate core indicators of performance for the secondary and postsecondary levels, and links established between secondary core indicators of performance and ESEA.
• The act requires eligible agencies and recipients to submit state and local plans, which must cover a six-year time period, and includes specific requirements for the contents of these plans, including the description of career and technical programs of study and the linkages to ESEA provisions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes are unified under the same rate structure and share a lifetime transfer credit, with the unified credit covering an applicable amount of $5,340,000 per individual in 2014.
* The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a decedent, levied against and paid by the estate, while the inheritance tax is imposed on and paid by the heirs of the decedent based upon the money or property they receive.
* The gross estate of a decedent includes the value of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, wherever situated, in which the decedent owned an interest on the date of the decedent's death, and is valued at its fair market value on the date of death or the alternate valuation date.
* The federal gift tax is a tax imposed on an annual basis on all gratuitous transfers of property made during life, and the tax liability is determined by the value of the taxable gift, which is the fair market value of the gift at the time it was made, less certain exclusions and deductions.
* The generation-skipping transfer tax is a flat-rate tax of 40% applied to three different transfer events: a direct skip, a taxable termination, or a taxable distribution, and is exempt up to $5,340,000 per individual, with the exemption doubled for married individuals who elect to treat the transfers as made one-half by each spouse.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a crucial function in protecting the American people from terrorists and their instruments of destruction, and the federal government has implemented various programs and policies to achieve this goal.
* The BTS function can be seen as a series of concentric circles or screens, with the outer screen being preventive efforts launched outside the country, and the process starts with prevention abroad and progresses through other stages as needed.
* The development of congressional concern and policy approaches began with inquiries related to the nature of the terrorist threat, followed by specific, targeted measures to protect the nation after the 9/11 attacks.
* The Homeland Security Act of 2002 consolidated many federal agencies responsible for border and transportation security into a single department, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
* The DHS has a Directorate of BTS, which is charged with securing the borders, territorial waters, terminals, waterways, and air, land, and sea transportation systems of the United States.
* The U.S. government has employed various strategies and programs to make the nation's borders more secure, including pushing the border outwards to intercept unwanted people or goods, hardening the border through technology and presence, making the border more accessible for legitimate trade and travel, strengthening the border through intelligence, and multiplying effectiveness through engagement of other actors.
* The use of technology, such as pre-inspections, advanced passenger manifests, and biometric identifiers, has been implemented to enhance border security and facilitate legitimate travel and trade.
* Intelligence plays a crucial role in border security, providing indications and warnings to government personnel responsible for border protection, and contributing to the protection of U.S. borders by seeking to prevent certain goods and individuals from crossing U.S. borders.
* The U.S. government has also engaged in bilateral efforts with Canada and Mexico to secure the border and facilitate the flow of low-risk travelers and goods, including the creation of a "smart border" and a "smart border" partnership action plan.

</summary>

<summary>
* Cabo Verde is a small island nation in West Africa with historical ties to the United States, and its relations with the US are based on its status as a model of democratic governance and economic stability.
* The country's strategic location makes it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe, and it has been a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic between Africa and the US.
* US-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects, including those supported by the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC).
* Cabo Verde has a high literacy rate (87% in 2015) and generally high social services and health indicators, although they are lower in rural areas.
* The country has a small national military of about 1,000 personnel, including a small coast guard, and is an active member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS).
* Cabo Verde has received substantial US development assistance administered under two MCC Compacts, which have supported projects such as water utility development and land registration system reform.
* The country has a bilateral Open Skies aviation services agreement with the US, and is eligible for African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) tariff preferences, although its exports to the US are relatively minor.
* Narcotics trafficking poses an increasing threat in Cabo Verde, and the US has provided assistance to help the country counter this threat, including through the International Military Education and Training (IMET) program and the West Africa Regional Security Initiative (WARSI).
* Cabo Verde has also engaged in cooperation efforts with the US Department of Defense's Africa Command (AFRICOM), including hosting multinational military exercises and receiving training visits from the US Coast Guard and Navy.
</summary>

<summary>
• The United States and New Zealand have strengthened their security partnership, with the two nations cooperating on defense and security issues, including maritime security, counterterrorism, and disaster relief in the Asia Pacific region. This partnership has been facilitated by the Wellington Declaration of 2010 and the Washington Declaration of 2012, which have provided a framework for the new strategic partnership between the two nations.
• New Zealand's foreign policy orientation has shifted over time, with the country increasingly focusing on its role as a Pacific nation and seeking to strengthen its ties with Asia, particularly China. The country's relationship with China is complex, with some viewing China as a threat and others seeing opportunities for cooperation and economic growth. The United States and New Zealand have a shared interest in promoting stability and security in the Asia Pacific region, and their partnership is likely to continue to play an important role in this effort.
</summary>

<summary>

• The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for the President to appoint officers: with the advice and consent of the Senate or unilaterally during the Senate's recess.

• President Obama faced difficulty in obtaining Senate confirmation for nominations to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).

• The President considered making recess appointments for the CFPB Director and NLRB members, but the Senate held pro forma sessions to prevent a recess.

• The President ultimately made recess appointments for Richard Cordray, Terrence F. Flynn, Sharon Block, and Richard F. Griffin Jr. on January 4, 2012.

• A court may consider whether the Senate's pro forma sessions constitute standard sessions of Congress, which could break up a long intrasession recess into shorter recesses.

• If a court finds that pro forma sessions are standard sessions, the President's recess appointments may be considered invalid, as they were made during a three-day recess.

• The Recess Appointments Clause does not explicitly define "Recess," but the Adjournment Clause may be used to inform its meaning.

• A court may consider whether a "Recess" must be longer than three days for the President to exercise his recess appointment power, based on the Adjournment Clause.

• The President's recess appointment power may be limited by the fact that Congress can prevent the President from making recess appointments by remaining continuously in session.

• The constitutionality of the President's recess appointments and the scope of the CFPB Director's powers under the Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFP Act) are subject to ongoing legal analysis and debate.

</summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has broad authority over the admission and exclusion of aliens seeking to enter the United States, and may deny admission without affording due process protections such as the right to a hearing. Aliens seeking entry are generally entitled only to those protections that Congress explicitly authorized.
* The expedited removal process, established by the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act (IIRIRA) of 1996, allows for the summary removal of certain arriving aliens who do not have valid entry documents or have attempted to gain their admission by fraud or misrepresentation. This process does not apply to all arriving aliens, but only to those who are inadmissible due to a lack of entry documents or attempting to procure admission through fraud or misrepresentation.
* The expedited removal process involves a series of determinations by multiple agencies and agency subcomponents, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS). Aliens in expedited removal proceedings are generally subject to detention pending a determination as to whether they should be removed from the United States.
* The expedited removal process has been subject to legal challenges since its implementation in 1997, with some courts holding that the process violates aliens' due process rights and others dismissing challenges for lack of jurisdiction. The Supreme Court has upheld the government's authority to detain aliens potentially indefinitely pending their removal proceedings, but has left unresolved the issue of whether such detention is constitutionally permissible.
</summary>

<summary>

* The principle of a republic is that the people should choose whom they please to govern them, which is embodied in congressional redistricting, the drawing of district boundaries from which the people choose their representatives to the U.S. House of Representatives.
* Prior to the 1960s, court challenges to redistricting plans were considered non-justiciable political questions, but in 1962, the Supreme Court held that a constitutional challenge to a redistricting plan was not a political question and was justiciable.
* The Supreme Court has issued a series of constitutional and legal challenges that have significantly shaped how congressional districts are drawn, and recent and pending cases will likely continue to impact the process of congressional redistricting.
* The Elections Clause of the Constitution provides that the times, places, and manner of holding congressional elections be prescribed in each state by the legislature thereof, but that Congress may at any time make or alter such laws.
* The Supreme Court has interpreted the Constitution to require that each congressional district within a state contain approximately the same population, known as the "equality standard" or the principle of "one person, one vote."
* The Voting Rights Act (VRA) requires congressional district boundaries to comply with Section 2, which prohibits any voting qualification or practice that results in the denial or abridgement of the right to vote based on race, color, or membership in a language minority.
* The Supreme Court has permitted state legislative districts a greater deviation from precise equality than congressional districts, but such deviation can be found to be improper if it is motivated by partisanship.
* The Court has also addressed the question of who should be counted (i.e., total population, eligible voters, or some other measure of population) within districts in order to achieve equality, and in Evenwel v. Abbott, the Court upheld a state's decision to draw its legislative districts based on total population.
* The creation of one or more "majority-minority" districts may be required in a congressional redistricting plan to avoid racial vote dilution, and the Supreme Court has established a three-prong test to determine whether a district is a majority-minority district.

</summary>

<summary>

* The severe fire seasons in the past decade have led to substantial debate and proposals related to fire protection programs and funding, with the federal government increasing funding to protect federal, state, and private lands.
* The National Fire Plan was proposed in 2000 by President Clinton to increase funding for fire protection, and the Healthy Forests Initiative was proposed in 2002 by President Bush to expedite fuel reduction on federal lands.
* The Federal Land Assistance, Management, and Enhancement (FLAME) Act was enacted in 2009 to insulate other agency programs from high wildfire suppression costs, and wildfire funding has continued at relatively high levels since 2000.
* The federal government has three categories of federal programs for wildfire protection: protection of federal lands, protection of non-federal lands, and fire research, fire facilities, and improvements in forest health.
* The federal government has increased its wildfire management costs, with federal wildfire appropriations averaging $1.1 billion for FY1994-FY1999 and $3.4 billion for FY2004-FY2009, and the average acreage burned has increased from 3.32 million acres annually for 1990-1999 to 6.93 million acres annually for 2000-2009.
* The federal government has also increased its fuel reduction efforts, with the acreage treated increasing by 400% from FY1995 to FY2004, but the annual fuel treatment acreage has stabilized at less than 3 million acres annually, which is less than 1% of federal lands.
* The federal government has proposed various solutions to address the high costs of wildfire management, including increasing state and local responsibility for fire protection, improving cost control and accountability, and integrating wildfire management in land and resource planning and budgeting.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Social Security system does not cover about 27.5% of state and local government employees, approximately 6.6 million people, with coverage rates varying across states.
* Congress made Social Security coverage mandatory for most state and local government employees who were not already covered by public pension plans, starting in July 1991.
* Currently, public employees who have a pension plan but are not covered by Social Security may hold a referendum on whether to elect Social Security coverage.
* Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees has been recommended by recent deficit reduction groups to increase the universality of the program and address its long-range financial status.
* Long-range projections show that Social Security expenditures will exceed income by 16% on average over the next 75 years, but mandatory coverage of newly hired state and local government employees is projected to have a net positive effect on the Social Security Trust Funds.
* Mandatory Social Security coverage could simplify retirement planning and benefit coordination for workers who divide their careers between state and local government positions and other positions.
* Opponents argue that mandatory Social Security coverage would not necessarily result in better benefit protections for workers, as state and local governments could reduce some pension benefits currently available under non-covered pension plans.
* The implementation of mandatory Social Security coverage would require states and localities to administer two different systems, one for existing non-covered employees and another for employees who are newly covered by Social Security, which could impose significant administrative burdens.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Trade Adjustment Assistance for Workers (TAA) program provides federal assistance to workers who involuntarily lose their jobs due to foreign competition, offering funding for training and reemployment services, income support, and tax credits for health insurance premiums.
* TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and states, with the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) making group eligibility determinations and overseeing grantees, while states provide individual benefits through local American Job Centers.
* To be eligible for TAA, a group of workers must petition DOL to establish that their job loss was attributable to foreign trade, and individual workers must meet specific conditions, including separation from the firm on or after the impact date and enrollment in an approved training program.
* TAA benefits include training and reemployment services, income support for workers who have exhausted their unemployment compensation benefits and are enrolled in training, and a tax credit for a portion of qualified health insurance premiums.
* The program has undergone several reauthorizations, with the most recent being the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA), which reinstated many of the eligibility and benefit provisions that were enacted by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Extension Act of 2011.
* The TAA program is scheduled to revert to a more limited set of eligibility and benefit provisions on July 1, 2021, and then begin to be phased out after June 30, 2022, unless reauthorized by Congress.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Federal Employee Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004 was enacted on December 23, 2004, requiring the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to establish arrangements for supplemental dental and vision benefits for federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.
• The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established by OPM, with coverage first available on December 31, 2006, and enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums.
• Eligible individuals can enroll in FEDVIP during the standard open season for FEHB plans, or following a qualifying life event, and may choose a self-only, self +1, or a family plan, with the option to enroll in one or both types of coverage.
• FEDVIP plans offer various benefits, including Class A (Basic) services, Class B (Intermediate) services, Class C (Major) services, and Class D (Orthodontic) services, with premiums varying by plan, geographic area, and residency.
• Decisions about FEDVIP enrollment should consider factors such as coverage of services in a FEHB plan, likelihood of using services, and the option to place the same dollar amount in an FSA, with the ability to revisit decisions every year during open season.
</summary>

<summary>

* The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) provided $17.15 billion in supplemental FY2009 discretionary appropriations for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
* ARRA included new authorizing language to promote the widespread adoption of electronic health records and other health information technology (HIT), and established a federal interagency advisory panel to coordinate comparative effectiveness research.
* The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) issued detailed government-wide guidance for implementing ARRA and established a website, "Recovery.gov," which allows the public to track ARRA spending.
* ARRA provided $2 billion to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for grants to health centers authorized under section 330 of the Public Health Service (PHS) Act, with $1.5 billion for health center infrastructure and $500 million for operating grants.
* The National Institutes of Health (NIH) received $10.0 billion directly from ARRA for biomedical research and extramural research facilities, with $8.2 billion for broad support of NIH scientific research and $1 billion for grants to construct and renovate university research facilities.
* ARRA provided $1.1 billion to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) for comparative effectiveness research (CER), with $300 million for AHRQ to invest in CER activities and $400 million transferred to NIH.
* The Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) received $2 billion from ARRA to fund activities and grant programs authorized by the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act, including $693 million for the Health IT Extension Program and $564 million for states and qualified state designated entities to facilitate electronic health information exchange.
* ARRA provided a total of $500 million for the Indian Health Service (IHS), with $415 million for IHS health facilities-related activities and $85 million for HIT activities, including funds for telehealth services and HIT-related infrastructure activities.

</summary>

<summary>
* The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) was enacted in 1999 to require meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The law has undergone several reauthorizations, with the most recent one extending mandatory price reporting until September 30, 2020.
* The LMR program has undergone changes over the years, including the addition of new reporting categories, such as negotiated formula purchase for swine, and the revision of confidentiality rules to improve data reporting. The program has also faced challenges, including the impact of government shutdowns on price reporting and the need for more timely hog marketing and price information.
</summary>

<summary>
* A sitting United States Senator's status and service are not directly affected by a federal indictment for a felony, and no rights or privileges are forfeited under the Constitution, statutory law, or Senate Rules.
* Members of Congress do not automatically forfeit their offices upon conviction of a felony, and there is no express constitutional disability or "disqualification" from Congress for the conviction of a crime, except for treasonous conduct after taking an oath of office.
* Conviction of certain crimes may subject Senators to internal legislative disciplinary proceedings, including resolutions of censure, and expulsion from the Senate upon approval of two-thirds of the Members.
* Indictment and/or conviction of a crime that is a felony does not constitutionally disqualify one from being a Member of Congress, unless a Member's conviction is for certain treasonous conduct committed after taking an oath of office to support the Constitution.
* Members of Congress may be subject to internal disciplinary action, including censure or expulsion, for misconduct, but the authority to expel would be used cautiously when the institution of Congress might be seen as usurping or supplanting its own institutional judgment for the judgment of the electorate.
* There is no law or Rule providing that a Member of the Senate who is indicted for or convicted of a crime must forfeit their congressional salary, and a person under indictment or a convicted felon may run for and be reelected to Congress if they meet the constitutional qualifications for office.
* A Member of Congress may lose their federal pension annuity or creditable service as a Member for federal pension purposes if convicted of certain crimes, including national security offenses and public corruption, abuse of official position, fraud, or campaign finance laws.
</summary>

<summary>
• There are approximately 766 million acres of forestlands in the United States, with 58% (445 million acres) being privately owned by individuals, families, Native American tribes, corporations, nongovernmental organizations, and other groups.
• The federal government has numerous programs to support forest management on private and public forests, primarily administered by the Forest Service (FS) in the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), with the assistance of state partner agencies.
• To be eligible for federal assistance, each state must prepare a State Forest Action Plan, which includes a statewide assessment of forest resource conditions, a long-term statewide forest resource strategy, and a description of the resources necessary to address the strategy.
• Funding for forestry assistance programs has declined over the past 15 years, with the average annual appropriation from FY2004 to FY2018 being $362.7 million, and the Administration requesting $197.4 million in FY2019, proposing to eliminate funding for seven programs and decrease funding for others.
</summary>

<summary>
* Transnational organized crime groups in Burma engage in various illicit activities, including drug trafficking, human trafficking, wildlife trafficking, and arms smuggling, generating billions of dollars in profits each year.
* Corruption among officials in Burma's ruling military junta, the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC), facilitates trafficking and provides immunity from law enforcement and judicial action.
* The country's border regions, characterized by difficult terrain and ethnic tensions, create "ungoverned spaces" that enable the proliferation of transnational crime.
* The U.S. government has imposed sanctions on Burma due to its role in transnational crime, including the Tom Lantos Block Burmese JADE Act of 2008, which prohibits the indirect import of Burmese gems.
* Burma is a major producer of illicit opium, heroin, and methamphetamine, with the United Wa State Army (UWSA) being the largest organized criminal group in the region, operating freely along the China and Thailand borders.
* The effectiveness of U.S. sanctions on Burma is limited by factors such as unevenly applied sanctions by other countries, a booming natural gas production industry, and China's continued economic and military assistance to Burma.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) has had a significant impact on federal mandatory spending, with most of the projected spending going towards expanding health insurance coverage.
* The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) reported that spending on premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions totaled $79.2 billion for the first three fiscal years (FY2014-FY2016) in which the ACA exchanges were operational.
* An analysis of preliminary data from the Medicaid Budget and Expenditure System (MBES) showed that 27 states that implemented the Medicaid expansion reported spending a total of $36.7 billion on newly eligible adults in calendar year 2014.
* The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that gross spending on insurance coverage expansion under the ACA will total $1.938 trillion over the 10-year period FY2017 through FY2026.
* The ACA also included numerous appropriations that provided billions of dollars in mandatory funds to support new and existing grant programs and other activities.
* The law established the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) within CMS and appropriated $10 billion for the FY2011-FY2019 period—and $10 billion for each subsequent 10-year period—for CMMI to test and implement innovative payment and service delivery models.
* The ACA created four special funds and appropriated substantial amounts to each one, including the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF), the Prevention and Public Health Fund (PPHF), the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Trust Fund (PCORTF), and the Health Insurance Reform Implementation Fund (HIRIF).
* Most of the ACA appropriations are temporary, but some have been extended through legislative actions, including the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012, the Pathway for SGR Reform Act of 2013, the Protecting Access to Medicare Act of 2014, and the Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act of 2015.
* The ACA funding extensions, reductions, and rescissions are summarized in Table 2 and Table 3, which provide additional details on each of the appropriations and fund transfers.
* The federal spending on insurance expansion coverage under the ACA is almost entirely exempt from annual sequestration, but the ACA appropriations discussed in this report are, in general, fully sequestrable at the percentage rate applicable to nonexempt nondefense mandatory spending.

</summary>

<summary>
• The increased presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs has been a concern for some in the scientific community, as enrollment of U.S. citizens in these programs has not kept pace.
• Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the United States, with many eventually becoming citizens.
• The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that employment in science and engineering fields will increase at a faster rate than other professional groups between 2006 and 2016.
• The H-1B temporary admissions program has been a focus of attention in the scientific community, with some arguing that it has contributed to a shortage of scientists and engineers in the United States.
• The Immigration Act of 1990 more than doubled employment-based immigration, including scientists and engineers entering under the H-1B visa category.
• The American Competitiveness in the Twenty-First Century Act of 2000 raised the annual number of H-1B visas to 195,000 for FY2001, FY2002, and FY2003, and returned to 65,000 in FY2004.
• Foreign students on temporary resident visas earned 32.0% of the doctorates in the sciences and 58.6% of the doctorates in engineering in 2006.
• The scientific community has been divided over proposals to impose stricter immigration limits on people with scientific and technical skills, with some arguing that it is necessary to protect U.S. workers and others arguing that it is necessary to bring in foreign talent to compete with other countries.
• The debate on the presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the workforce intensified following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and has continued to be a topic of discussion in the scientific community.
• Comprehensive immigration reform legislation has been reintroduced in the 111th Congress, which would exempt specified categories of U.S.-educated immigrants from employment-based immigration limits and amend H-1B visa employer application requirements.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) receive funding from the annual Energy and Water Development Appropriations bill. 
* The FY2018 budget request from President Trump proposes a 9.5% decrease in funding for the DOE, with nearly half of the reduction coming from EERE programs, resulting in a nearly 70% decrease from FY2017.
* The proposed budget would eliminate two EERE programs: the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program, and would focus on "early-stage R&D" with a decrease in funding for later-stage R&D and deployment projects.
* The House and Senate appropriations bills, H.R. 3219 and S. 1609, provide funding for EERE above the Administration's request, with S. 1609 providing the highest level of funding, and both bills supporting continued research and development in various areas, including solar energy, wind energy, and energy efficiency.
* The final appropriations bill, P.L. 115-56, provides appropriations at the FY2017 level through December 8, 2017, and the issues of EERE funding and priorities remain before the 115th Congress.
</summary>

<summary>
• The first known cryptocurrency, Bitcoin, was created in 2008 by an unknown programmer or group of programmers using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto. It is a digital representation of value that allows users to make valid transfers without the need for a centralized intermediary.

• Cryptocurrencies have evolved from being little-known technological curiosities to rapidly proliferating financial instruments, with some government central banks examining the possibility of issuing their own digital currencies.

• The traditional monetary system involves government-issued fiat money, which derives its value from government decree rather than intrinsic value. The value of fiat money is maintained by the government through control of the money supply and anti-counterfeiting measures.

• Cryptocurrencies, on the other hand, use blockchain technology to validate transactions and maintain a decentralized, public ledger of accounts. This allows for secure and transparent transactions without the need for intermediaries.

• However, cryptocurrencies face several challenges to widespread adoption, including their limited use as a medium of exchange, their volatility, and their scalability issues. They also raise concerns about their potential use in facilitating criminal activity and the lack of consumer protections applicable to parties buying or using cryptocurrency.

• Some central banks are exploring the idea of issuing their own digital currencies, known as central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), which could provide certain benefits such as increased efficiency and stability. However, the potential impact of CBDCs on monetary policy and the economy is still unclear.
</summary>

<summary>

* The U.S. Bankruptcy Code's Chapter 11 allows financially troubled businesses to reorganize and remain in business rather than liquidate, with the debtor generally remaining in possession and no trustee being appointed.
* In a Chapter 11 reorganization, the debtor may assume or reject executory contracts, including collective bargaining agreements (CBAs), but rejection of CBAs is subject to a higher standard under Section 1113 of the Bankruptcy Code.
* Section 1113 requires the debtor to meet specific requirements before a court can approve rejection of a CBA, including presenting a proposal that treats all parties equitably and proposes changes necessary for reorganization.
* H.R. 3652, a proposed bill, would modify several sections of the Bankruptcy Code, including Section 1113, to provide greater protections for labor groups and employees in business bankruptcies.
* The bill would limit the modifications to the existing CBA that can be proposed by the debtor, requiring that they be no more than two years in duration and the minimum savings necessary for the debtor to exit bankruptcy.
* The bill would also require the debtor to provide the representative with information needed to evaluate the proposal and to bargain in good faith.
* The bill would establish a presumption that the debtor has overly burdened the labor group in comparison to the burdens on other groups, including management, if it has implemented a program of incentive pay for insiders or senior management personnel.
* The bill would extend the period required for notice to at least 21 days and restrict the parties who could appear and be heard at the rejection hearing to only the debtor and the authorized representative.
* The bill would also provide for arbitration in lieu of a court hearing to rule on a motion for rejection of a CBA, and would require the debtor and authorized representative to meet to determine the effects on the labor group when a debtor's reorganization plan involves selling all or part of the business.
* The bill's proposed changes would constrain both debtor companies and the courts when debtors file under Chapter 11, and would provide labor groups with a greater role in determining the feasibility of reorganization.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) received $1,546 million for Title I components in FY2016, which is $405 million (35.5%) more than was provided for FY2015 and $150 million (10.7%) more than was requested.
* The Administration requested $1,396 million in total budgetary resources for the Departmental Management and Operations accounts in FY2016, an increase of $255 million (22.3%) above the FY2015 enacted level.
* The Office of the Secretary and Executive Management (OSEM) received $137 million for FY2016, which is $3.2 million (2.4%) more than requested, and the Office of the Under Secretary for Management (USM) received $197 million, which is $3.6 million (1.9%) more than requested.
* The Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO) received $109 million for FY2016, which is almost $13 million (13%) more than requested, and the Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO) received $310 million, which is almost $11 million (3.3%) less than requested.
* The Analysis and Operations account received $265 million for FY2016, which is $4 million below the amount requested by the Administration, and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) received $137 million, which is almost $5 million (3.4%) below the amount requested.

</summary>

<summary>
• The distinction between net job loss and gross job loss is crucial in understanding the labor market, with net job loss being the result of greater gross job loss than gross job gains in a given period, and gross job loss being the total number of jobs eliminated by all contracting firms in a given period.
• The U.S. labor market is characterized by net job creation amidst gross job loss in expansions, and only during recessions does the overall labor market experience persistent net job loss.
• Gross job loss is not incompatible with a healthy labor market, as it is often offset by gross job gains, and most of the gross job flows occur at existing firms, not due to new firms opening or old firms closing.
• Trade liberalization has no effect on net employment, as economic theory states that expansions in trade have no effect on net employment, and historical evidence confirms this conclusion, with the implementation of trade liberalization agreements having virtually no relationship to changes in net employment.
• Offshore outsourcing or offshoring also does not cause net job loss, as it leads to gross job loss, but is offset by gross job gains in other sectors, such as the export sector or interest-sensitive sectors.
• Economic restructuring, such as the decline in manufacturing employment, is primarily attributable to rapid technological change and efficiency gains, not trade, and is a normal part of a market economy.
• Policymakers can use expansionary monetary or fiscal policy to stimulate aggregate spending and offset net job loss, but direct job creation programs and policies to impede gross job loss may have unintended consequences and be counterproductive.
</summary>

<summary>

• Shinzo Abe has been Japan's prime minister since December 2012, and his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has maintained control of Japan's legislature, ensuring his continued leadership.

• Abe's victory in the LDP leadership contest means he will continue serving as premier, and if he remains in power beyond November 2019, he will become the longest-serving prime minister in the history of modern Japan.

• Abe's new Cabinet includes one woman, down from two, despite his campaign to increase women's representation in government and participation in the workforce.

• The U.S.-Japan relationship has been strengthened by a shared approach to confronting the North Korean threat, but tensions have risen due to Trump's shift on North Korea and his statements critical of the value of alliances generally and Japan specifically.

• Japan and China appear to be seeking stability in their bilateral relationship, with Abe scheduled to visit Beijing in late October for a leaders' summit to deepen economic cooperation and increase people-to-people exchanges.

• Japan's relations with South Korea remain precarious due to historical grievances, particularly over the issue of Korean comfort women who were forced to provide sex to Japanese soldiers in the World War II era.

• The U.S.-Japan alliance has long been an anchor of the U.S. security role in Asia, with about 50,000 U.S. troops stationed in Japan and the United States guaranteeing Japan's security, including through extended deterrence.

• The Abe Administration has promoted a relatively pronuclear policy, despite persistent antinuclear sentiment among the public, and has released a Strategic Energy Plan that identifies nuclear power as an "important base-load power source" and aims to have nuclear energy account for 20-22% of Japan's power supply by 2030.

</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Homeland Security's Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is responsible for providing medical care to noncitizens in detention, but there have been reports of inadequate care, including delayed or denied medical treatment, and difficulties in accessing medication and medical records.
* ICE's National Detention Standards outline the minimum requirements for medical care, but critics argue that the standards are not being followed, and that the Division of Immigrant Health Services (DIHS) has too much influence over the provision of medical care, which can lead to inconsistent and inadequate care.
* There are ongoing debates about the appropriate standard of care for aliens in detention, with some arguing that the cost of care should be a consideration, while others argue that the health care provided to detained aliens should be similar to that provided to U.S. citizens, and that the health care system should be equipped to deal with the specific physical and psychological needs of asylum seekers.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) was created in 2004 as a new foreign aid initiative by the US government, with the goal of providing funding to countries that have demonstrated a commitment to sound development policies and good governance. The MCA is a performance-based program that selects countries based on their records in three areas: ruling justly, investing in people, and pursuing sound economic policies.
• The MCA has faced several challenges and debates, including issues related to income eligibility, performance indicators, and the role of the Board of Directors. The program has also been criticized for its potential to create a two-class aid system, with the MCC managing the largest and most visible programs, while USAID continues to manage smaller and more traditional aid programs.
</summary>

<summary>
• The 112th Congress is considering an omnibus farm bill that will establish the direction of agricultural policy for the next several years, with the Senate Agriculture Committee approving its version on April 26, 2012, and the House Agriculture Committee completing markup of its version on July 11, 2012.
• The Senate-passed farm bill (S. 3240) and the House Agriculture Committee-reported bill (H.R. 6083) both aim to reduce spending by $23.1 billion and $35.1 billion, respectively, over the next 10 years, with the Senate bill reducing the farm program payment limit to $50,000 per person and the House bill setting the limit at $125,000.
• Both bills make significant changes to farm commodity programs, including the elimination of direct payments, the creation of new revenue programs, and the reauthorization of disaster programs, with the Senate bill providing for a revised revenue program called Agriculture Risk Coverage (ARC) and the House bill retaining a counter-cyclical price program and a revenue program.
• The bills also address conservation programs, trade, nutrition, and rural development, with the Senate bill consolidating conservation programs, reauthorizing funding for international food aid programs, and increasing mandatory funding for the Specialty Crop Research Initiative and the Organic Agricultural Research and Extension Initiative, while the House bill makes funding authorization amendments to many existing rural development programs.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Inland Waterway System (IWS) is a significant component of the nation's marine transportation system, carrying approximately one-sixth of the national volume of intercity cargo on 25,000 miles of commercially active inland and intracoastal waterways.
* The IWS is managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) and covers 38 states, handling approximately half of all inland waterway freight.
* The Corps develops, operates, and maintains the infrastructure of these commercial waterways, and also maintains and regulates the channel depths through dredging and water management.
* The current revenue source for the IWS, a set tax on fuel agreed to in the mid-1980s, is insufficient to cover the nonfederal costs of major capital expenditures on inland waterways.
* The ongoing shortfall is currently limiting the number of new and ongoing inland waterway construction projects, and is expected to continue to do so unless changes to the financing system are enacted by Congress.
* The Inland Waterways Revenue Act of 1978 and the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 1986 established a fuel tax on commercial barges, cost-share requirements for inland waterway projects, and a trust fund to hold these revenues and fund investments in construction.
* The Inland Waterways Trust Fund (IWTF) balance has varied considerably between 1986 and 2011, with balances increasing from 1992 to 2002, and then falling sharply from 2005 to 2010.
* The IWUB has proposed a new financing system for inland waterways, including an increase to the existing fuel tax, an increase in the federal share of inland waterway costs, and an overall increase in funding for inland waterways.
* The IWUB proposal would shift the overall costs for inland waterway projects toward the federal government, with the federal government responsible for approximately 68% of the costs, and the non-federal entities responsible for approximately 32%.

</summary>

<summary>

• Congress has used commemoratives to express public gratitude, dramatize virtues, and perpetuate remembrance since its inception, with various forms including medals, special days, monuments, and coins.

• The 104th Congress introduced House Rule XII, clause 5, which prohibits the introduction and consideration of date-specific commemorative legislation, with some exceptions for presidential proclamations and certain types of commemorations.

• The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform has a rule against considering legislation that proposes the issuance of commemorative stamps, and the Postmaster General has discretionary authority to create semipostal stamps.

• Commemorative coins are produced by the U.S. Mint pursuant to an act of Congress, with over 140 new coins authorized since 1892, and the Commemorative Coin Reform Act of 1996 limiting the number of coins minted per year.

• Congressional Gold Medals are awarded on an ad hoc basis, with the House Republican Conference rule requiring that the recipient be a natural person, have performed a significant achievement, and meet other criteria.

• The Commemorative Works Act of 1986 provides standards for the consideration and placement of monuments and memorials in the District of Columbia, requiring congressional authorization for new works.

• Commemorative commissions are entities established to oversee the commemoration of a person or event, with various options for organizational structure and powers, and funded through appropriations or solicitation of nonfederal money.

• Nonlegislative options for commemoration include certificates of recognition, floor speeches, and the purchasing of American flags, with restrictions on the use of official funds for certain purposes in the House and Senate.

</summary>

<summary>

* The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 (P.L. 111-358) was signed by President Obama on January 4, 2011, to increase funding for research in physical sciences and engineering, and to authorize STEM education programs and policies.
* The law authorized approximately $45.5 billion in funding between FY2010 and FY2013 for federal research in physical sciences and engineering, STEM education, and other related programs.
* The President's FY2013 budget request for the National Science Foundation (NSF) was $5.983 billion, which was $225 million more than the FY2012 actual level but $654.5 million less than the COMPETES 2010 authorized amount.
* The President's FY2013 budget request for the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Science was $4.992 billion, which was $57 million more than the FY2012 current plan funding level but $1.009 billion less than the authorized level in COMPETES 2010.
* The FY2013 post-rescission, post-sequestration funding for NSF was $6.884 billion, which was $220.6 million less than the FY2012 actual funding level and $1.416 billion less than the COMPETES 2010 authorized funding level.
* The FY2013 post-rescission, post-sequestration funding for the DOE Office of Science was $4.621 billion, which was $313.9 million less than the FY2012 current funding level and $1.380 billion less than the COMPETES 2010 authorized funding level.
* The FY2013 funding levels for COMPETES 2010 accounts were generally below FY2010 levels, and the combined effects of sequestration, rescissions, and funding levels in the final FY2013 appropriations act decreased funding levels for many accounts below FY2010 actual levels.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Lacey Act was enacted in 1900 to address game poaching and wildlife laundering, and was amended in 2008 to include nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws.
* The Lacey Act regulates the trade of wildlife and plants, and creates penalties for a broad spectrum of violations, including domestic and international illegal trade of plants and wildlife.
* The 2008 amendments expanded the definition of a plant to include any wild member of the plant kingdom, including roots, seeds, parts, or products thereof, and any trees from either natural or planted forest stands.
* The law requires importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at the time of importation, which must contain certain information such as identification of the species and genus of plants or plants used in a product.
* The declaration requirements were implemented in phases, with some products being declared by April 2010, and others being considered for phased-in implementation.
* The Lacey Act can be enforced at the border or through investigations, and agents at ports of entry inspect imports and monitor the declaration process.
* The law requires that the importer exercise due care in determining if the imported plants or plant products were legally harvested, processed, and exported, and that they take steps to ensure compliance with the law.
* The due care standard is pivotal for determining penalties under the Lacey Act, and exercising due care can reduce the potential for abusive and indiscriminate enforcement efforts.
* The Lacey Act has been amended to include provisions for reducing illegal logging, and has been the subject of controversy and proposed changes, including modifications to the declaration requirements and the due care standard.

</summary>

<summary>
* The 2002 Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA) introduced a new counter-cyclical assistance program to support farmers during periods of low prices and incomes. The program provides fixed payments and target price deficiency payments to eligible producers, with the payments based on historical production and not tied to current planting rules.
* The new program is expected to cost $98.9 billion over 6 years, with $23.6 billion of that cost attributed to the new counter-cyclical payments for grains, cotton, and oilseeds. However, the actual cost may be higher or lower depending on future market conditions, and there are concerns about the program's potential impact on world trade commitments and the distribution of benefits among different commodity groups.
</summary>

<summary>
• The United States and Vietnam established diplomatic relations in 1995, and since then, the two countries have expanded relations and cooperation across various sectors, including nuclear energy.
• A civilian nuclear cooperation agreement was initialed by the two countries in December 2013 and signed in May 2014 under Section 123 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, which allows for the export of nuclear reactors and components.
• The agreement was subject to congressional review, and at least four issues were prominent during the review period, including nonproliferation commitments, Vietnam's human rights record, the strategic relationship between the US and Vietnam, and the benefits for US companies.
• Vietnam has nuclear cooperation agreements with Russia, France, China, South Korea, Japan, and Canada, and the US nuclear industry contends that billions of dollars of exports could result from the Vietnam 123 agreement.
• Vietnam plans to build its first nuclear power plants in the coming decades, with nuclear power projected to provide 20-30% of the country's electricity by 2050, and the country has already begun construction on two 1,000 MWe reactors at Phuoc Dinh.
• The US and Vietnam have strengthened their nonproliferation policies, with Vietnam committing to rely on international markets for its nuclear fuel supply and the US promising to support international markets to ensure a reliable nuclear fuel supply for Vietnam.
• The US-Vietnam nuclear cooperation agreement has been the end-goal of engagement in the nuclear field since the 2010 Memorandum of Understanding, and its approval by Congress could have an impact on future US-Vietnamese cooperation, including in the nuclear area.
</summary>

<summary>
* In 2005, North Korea escalated the security situation on the Korean peninsula through words and actions, including announcing it had nuclear weapons and suspending participation in the Six-Party Talks. Despite a joint statement of principles agreed to in September, which committed North Korea to abandoning all nuclear weapons, the talks stalled again, and hostile rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang intensified.
* The year 2005 saw little progress in resolving the North Korea nuclear issue, with the U.S. and its allies imposing penalties on Banco Delta Asia, a Macau bank allegedly involved in laundering U.S. dollars counterfeited by North Korea, and criticizing North Korea's human rights record. China, however, continued to provide food assistance to North Korea and urged Pyongyang not to use the issue as a reason to boycott the Six-Party Talks.
* Despite tensions between the U.S. and South Korea over their approaches to North Korea, the two countries reaffirmed their shared strategic goal of eliminating North Korea's nuclear weapons program through a diplomatic process. China's leadership in the Six-Party Talks was praised, and its strategy of balancing its interests with both North and South Korea was seen as largely successful in serving its national interests.
</summary>

<summary>
* The study compared two methods for increasing proteome coverage: repetitive LC-MS/MS runs and an additional protein level separation step using microsol ief. The results showed that the 3-d method, which included microsol ief, provided superior protein and peptide coverage compared to the 2-d method with repetitive runs, identifying 22% more proteins and 2.5 times more peptides.
* The study also evaluated the reproducibility of protein lists between the two methods and found that the apparent differences in protein identifications were due to limitations of current sequence databases and protein naming conventions, as well as software limitations for filtering database search results and building consensus protein lists, rather than undersampling during data acquisition.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study compared the incidence of secondary, delayed postoperative hemorrhage between tonsillectomy and submucosal uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (SMUPPP) procedures, finding a significant difference in the rate of hemorrhage between the two groups, with SMUPPP having a lower incidence of bleeding.
• The study suggests that the suturing technique used in SMUPPP, including suturing both the muscular and mucosal layers of the tonsillar fossa and using bipolar cauterization followed by tacking with 3-0 vicryl sutures, may be responsible for the lower incidence of postoperative bleeding, and recommends routine use of this technique to reduce the rate of postoperative hemorrhage.
</summary>

<summary>

* The - and -lactam scaffolds are found in various biologically relevant compounds and are crucial intermediates in the synthesis of natural products and pharmaceuticals.
* The authors have explored the synthesis of -lactams by the reactions of aryl-, thioaryl-, and cyano-substituted anhydrides.
* One-pot four-component reactions (4CRs) are possible in the case of thioaryl substitution.
* Recent computational studies demonstrate that cyanosuccinic anhydride reactions proceed by a Mannich-like mechanism via the enol tautomer of the anhydride.
* The authors have successfully synthesized various sulfone-substituted - and -lactams in good yields with high diastereoselectivities (>95:5) by an anhydride Mannich reaction.
* The reaction of imines with sulfone-substituted anhydrides forms -lactams, and the carboxylic acid intermediates can be trapped with trimethylsilyldiazomethane (TMSCHN2).
* The diastereoselectivity of the reaction can be controlled by resident stereogenic centers.
* The authors have demonstrated the versatility of the anhydride Mannich reaction of sulfone-substituted anhydrides in the assembly of heterocyclic targets.
* A formal synthesis of ( )-isoretronecanol was achieved using the anhydride Mannich reaction.
* The reaction tolerated a variety of non-enolizable aldehydes and a variety of alkylamines and anilines.

</summary>

<summary>
• The morbidity of breast cancer is increasing, and early detection and accurate analysis of molecular biology characteristics are crucial. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play a significant role in the invasion and development of breast cancer, and their expression levels can be used as markers for early diagnosis.
• The study investigated the expression levels of five miRNAs (mir-125a, mir-206, mir-145, mir-21, and mir-10b) in breast cancer tissues and para-carcinoma tissues. The results showed that mir-145 and mir-206 were expressed at lower levels in breast cancer tissues, while mir-21 and mir-10b were expressed at higher levels.
• The study found that mir-145 and mir-206 were negatively correlated with tumor size and lymph node metastasis, while mir-21 was positively correlated with lymph node metastasis and positive HER-2 expression. Mir-10b was related to tumor size, lymph node metastasis, and positive TOP2A expression.
• The study suggested that mir-145, mir-206, mir-125a, and mir-21 may be involved in the suppression of breast cancer invasion and metastasis, and may be used as novel tumor markers for the diagnosis and prognosis of breast cancer. Mir-21 and mir-125a could contribute to the treatment of HER-2-positive breast cancer cells, while mir-145 and mir-206 could accelerate the development of treatment methods for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
• The study highlighted the potential of miRNAs as biomarkers for breast cancer diagnosis and prognosis, and as targets for therapy. However, further investigations are needed to verify the detailed mechanism and clinical applications of these miRNAs.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study investigates the role of tissue transglutaminase 2 (tgm2) in the pathogenesis of chronic allograft injury (cai) in a rat model of renal transplantation. 
• Tgm2 is overexpressed by mononuclear leukocytes, predominantly by activated monocytes, which accumulate in the vascular bed of rat renal allografts on day 9 after transplantation.
• The expression of tgm2 is also induced in graft tissue upon allogenic transplantation, but no significant increase in protein signals was seen.
• The study suggests that tgm2 expression by blood monocytes in vivo has not been described before, and it is unclear if tgm2 expression is confined to m2-like monocytes.
• The functional relevance of tgm2 expression by m2 macrophages is still elusive, and its role in monocytes is unclear.
• The study found that tgm2 expression by blood mononuclear cells might be linked to apoptosis, and activation of caspase-3 was more visible in veins compared to arteries.
• The study did not support the hypothesis that tgm2 expressed by graft monocytes during reversible acute rejection contributes to an early induction of cai, but more research is needed to fully understand the role of tgm2 in the pathogenesis of cai.
</summary>

<summary>
* Endothelial cells (HUVEC passage 46) were grown to confluence and stimulated with plasminogen activation inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) to produce endothelial microparticles (EMPs).
* The supernatant was collected, centrifuged, and ultracentrifuged to isolate EMPs, which were then re-suspended in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and stored at -80°C.
* Flow cytometric analysis was used to characterize and quantify EMPs based on CD31- and Annexin V-positivity occurring in a size gate less than 1 μm.
* EMP levels were measured in a model patient's circulation using a CVVH filter and counter-current dialysis, with 50% clearance seen in the first 30 minutes.
* The circulating EMP levels were reduced to 29% of the starting concentration within 40 minutes and remained relatively constant over the duration of the study.
* The dialysate contained 5.7% of the original EMP concentration at the end of 4 hours of uninterrupted dialysis.
* The study demonstrates that CVVH can remove EMPs from a modelled patient's circulation, supporting the idea of CVVH as a meaningful therapeutic intervention in acute lung injury (ALI).
* The observed EMP clearance is likely a saturable phenomenon, and the relative volume of human circulation to CVVH circuit is a limitation of the model.
* The authors suggest that frequent changing of the CVVH filter and using a selective filter with convection and pressure gradients could overcome the limitations of the model and improve EMP clearance.
</summary>

<summary>

* Patients with frequent angina (1 episode per week) report greater physical limitations and decreased quality of life compared to those with minimal angina, highlighting the importance of effective management strategies.
* The goals of chronic stable angina management include controlling symptoms and reducing the risk of adverse clinical outcomes, with optimal medical therapy being a key component.
* Sublingual nitroglycerin spray has been shown to increase exercise tolerance and reduce angina symptoms in patients with stable angina, making it a valuable addition to optimal medical therapy.
* A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study evaluated the efficacy and safety of sublingual nitroglycerin spray in patients with stable angina, demonstrating a significant improvement in exercise tolerance and a dose-dependent increase in time to onset of moderate angina.
* The study found that the incidence of treatment-related adverse events increased with higher dose levels, with headache and dizziness being the most frequently reported adverse events.
* The results of this study support the use of sublingual nitroglycerin spray as nitrate therapy in patients with stable angina who are being managed with optimal medical therapy.
* Current guidelines recommend the initial use of medical therapy for patients with stable angina, with a focus on optimal medical therapy and lifestyle modifications, including supervised exercise therapy.
* Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term beneficial effects of using routine prophylactic nitroglycerin spray in patients with stable angina to increase exercise duration and improve quality of life and well-being.

</summary>

<summary>
* The presence of residual and resistant microorganisms, including fungi, is a major reason for failures in root canal treatments.
* Candida albicans, a type of fungus, has been found in 20% of endodontic treatment failures and is considered a dentinophilic microorganism.
* The presence of Candida albicans in endodontic treatment failures may be due to coronal leakage or contamination during treatment.
* Mineral Trioxide Aggregate (MTA) is a widely used root-end filling material with excellent sealing ability, biocompatibility, and antimicrobial effects.
* MTA-Angelus is a variation of MTA with improved properties, including good marginal adaptation and sealing ability.
* A study compared the antifungal properties of MTA and MTA-Angelus against Candida albicans using a tube-dilution test.
* The results showed that both MTA and MTA-Angelus were effective in eliminating Candida albicans at 24 hours, but not at 1 hour.
* The study concluded that MTA-Angelus has an effective antifungal property comparable to MTA at concentrations of 50 and 100 mg/ml, and that further studies are necessary to investigate the effect of these materials on bacteria and fungi in clinical application.
</summary>

<summary>
* After a stroke, patients often experience motor and sensory deficits on the side of the brain opposite to the damaged hemisphere, but recent studies suggest that the side of the brain opposite to the damaged hemisphere may also be affected.
* Ipsilateral motor deficits, which occur on the same side as the damaged hemisphere, have been found to emerge during the acute phase of stroke and persist chronically.
* Clinical assessment tools may not be sufficient to differentiate ipsilateral motor deficits, but laboratory testing has identified deficits in dexterous motor and coordination function on the ipsilateral side.
* Recent studies have found kinematic deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb in performance of various specific motor tasks requiring dexterity and coordination.
* Several possible mechanisms for ipsilateral motor deficits have been suggested, including disrupted counterbalance of each hemisphere, dysfunction of the uncrossed corticospinal track, or the different roles of both sides in hemispheric functions.
* The current study aimed to investigate the presence of motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb of stroke patients using a tracking and reposition sense test.
* The study found that stroke patients had a lower accuracy index in the tracking task and higher error scores in the joint reposition test compared to sex- and age-matched normal subjects.
* There was a significant correlation between ipsilateral motor deficits and sensory deficits, indicating that stroke patients would have difficulty performing complicated motor tasks requiring delicate sensoriomotor functions.
* The study suggests that interest in the ipsilateral side of stroke patients should focus on both ipsilateral motor and sensory deficits, and that the difficulty stroke patients experience in task performance using the ipsilateral upper limb may be affected by both motor and sensory deficits.
</summary>

<summary>
* The researchers have developed a post-coupling methodology to attach integrin-targeting peptides to the surface of nanoparticles, allowing for receptor-mediated cellular uptake of agents to cells. This approach has been shown to be effective in delivering imaging agents and small interfering RNA (siRNA) to cells, and has the potential to be used for the treatment of various diseases.
* The researchers have identified three key biophysical parameters that are necessary for receptor-mediated cell entry: nanoparticle dimensions of approximately 100 nm in diameter, nanoparticle potential values that converge on neutral (0 mV), and nanoparticle ligand surface coverage of approximately 2 mol% (or higher). These parameters are thought to be general rules for receptor-mediated cellular uptake of nanoparticle systems by corresponding receptor-expressing cells.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Millennium Cohort Study is a prospective study conducted by the Department of Defense (DoD) to investigate the relationship between military service and health outcomes, including diabetes.
* The study began in 2001 and included 77,047 participants, with 55,021 completing follow-up surveys at year 3 and 54,790 at year 6.
* Incident diabetes was the outcome of interest, and participants were excluded if they reported provider-diagnosed diabetes at baseline, missing outcome or exposure data, or type 1 diabetes.
* The study found that trouble sleeping, sleep duration of 5 hours, and sleep apnea were associated with a higher risk of incident diabetes.
